product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: A step up from the 8GB version if you must use your Kindle for audio.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on November 14, 2021
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: This is a copy of my main review in the 8GB device category appended with differences for this 32GB version. 4 stars unless you don't need the space, and then it becomes redundant and too expensive.The 32GB version is in my opinion a bit overboard for most people, but if you have money to spend, it is probably the version you should get, especially if you enjoy audio books. The extra memory to me amounts to useless space, but I personally do not use audiobooks or books with larger file sizes.I have a fairly large library, and that still was working out alright on my 7th gen with 4GB or less. For certain users, this will be the proper device to get. For others, they should look at the 8GB model, or perhaps using your phone for audio. I highly recommend the "essentials" bundles to save money.A normal user could have 2000-3000 normal books on their device with the 8GB. Seeing as a ton of my books are Delphi collections, this amounts to even more books relative to the average sizing around 2-4MB or so. Fact is, most people simply don't need this space, and it is useless for most by the time they upgrade due to batteries becoming less efficient. Audiobooks tend to take a lot more space, and it might be for this user that the 32GB is most appropriate.You can hold 20-40 audiobooks on an 8GB device, so for people that must have audiobooks on a Kindle, as opposed to their smartphone with better speakers and more memory, then maybe this is for you. But I would prefer audio on a device of my choosing that had better options for sound.The wireless charging is basically not a deal changer for me. I highly recommend having wireless off on the Kindle to save battery. Charging it works much the same as any device, but cords work fine for me as well, especially with the updated USB-C design. The auto-light is awkward mostly, and I have never used it on any device with one. For the extra money, I only find this device useful for people that absolutely need audio for their Paperwhite device.In full I simply will not use the extra space, and the other features are useless. Others may find them more appropriate. I don't see the point in paying Amazon more money. The lifeline of this device depends on the battery, and by the time I need 32GB, if that ever happens, I will be getting a new device. Not bad, but too expensive, as I mostly use physical books anyway.Overall Review for the Paperwhite 2021 (Four Stars):Summary:+ Best screen of any Paperwhite or Kindle released to date+ Best response time of any Paperwhite or Kindle+ UI improvements+ Weight and feel are exceptional- Screen has uneven area with color temp on high brightness- Expensive- Previous Kindles still do things in much the same wayComing from the 7th gen Kindle, this is a gigantic improvement on all fronts. The Paperwhite 2021 also handily beats the pulp out of the Paperwhite 2018 version due to its new LED array, and for my money it's a better choice than the Oasis 3 as well due to ergonomics. Add in some extra screen real estate compared to previous Paperwhites, a much nicer bezel, a few more options for the UI, and what we have is an extremely polished device for reading digital books. It's never going to make me switch totally from physical, but I will definitely be using this to read a lot more than my previous Kindle.The screen here is nearly perfect, and it will be the main factor attracting those coming from the previous 2018 model. If things were cheaper, this would be an essential upgrade for most people. I would not do without it if given the choice. Feel free to browse all the negative reviews from 2018. They were all right. But now it seems Amazon has finally finished their beta device. The screen itself is more matte than shiny, easy to wipe off, clear but not distracting, and fully able to replicate a physical book with its expanded dimensions. The Oasis 3 for instance irritates me with its form factor. The Paperwhite 2018 has an ugly bezel as well. This is exactly what I wanted out of an E-Reader.The Paperwhite 2021 is lit by 17 LEDs compared to 5 LEDs in the 2018 model, which leads to vastly superior balance. There are 24 gradations for both brightness and warmth, from off to mango warm, and they make a tangible and visible difference in proper aesthetics related to actual physical books. The color options are great, but after some use there still seems to be a portion equating to about the bottom half of the screen on mine that is a very slightly greener hue as opposed to a warmer hue on top. Very hard to pick up for some people, but it's worth noting for users that want to use this on high brightness. I usually only use around 6-12 brightness to get proper coloring, and it's not really noticeable in lit rooms with these settings. I usually use the lovely dark mode at night, so in the end I'll say this issue really doesn't affect me much.Make no mistake, though, the 2018 Paperwhite had an awful screen, with a horrendous LED array, and this one is a massive upgrade. This 2021 version still  has a fully stable lighting array that doesn't evoke a poor production run or haste in design, yet it's not perfect either. Blacks could definitely be deeper with an OLED screen or something of the sort. Dark Mode still looks good, but on higher brightness it appears a little too grey. Overall, I am satisfied at the advances that have been made, and my usual settings all look fantastic and so much better than anything before.6.8 inches of screen along with 300 PPI is definitely enough to satisfy most demands for resolution, and the extra space may be convincing for one to switch from physical books. The bezel itself also looks properly designed finally. That alone is also another huge deal. The sides are thin, the screen is the main attraction, and there is no awkwardness in reading versus a real book. All additions that make this is a positive buy over the other Kindles.There is an extremely tiny trail of adhesive in one corner and edge at the very bottom right near the backing material and black area of the bezel. Pretty minor all told. Most won't even notice things like this, and most Kindles will probably have such a minor flaw. Compared to the 2018 version, this thing seems like an actual professional product.The UI responsiveness was another issue in previous models, and I am happy to report this one is very fast. Massively faster than my 7th gen, and a decent improvement over the older model. The Paperwhite 2018 uses a Freescale/NXP i.MX6 SoloLite 1 GHz processor. Not terrible, but also not quite enough to match the newer NXP i.MX7D 1 GHz chip used in the Oasis 3 and this model. Again, a more refined version at every level compared to the older Paperwhite.For memory and storage, I can't see many people needing more than 8GB. I did fine on my last Kindle with much less. Unless you plan on starting a small library, 8GB of memory is a perfect fit for anyone's lifetime.As for the user interface, major changes have resulted in a much better flow in overall design for most Kindles from 2015 onward. The swipe down mechanic is leagues better than anything they've had before. The library UI that you tap in the upper left is again fast and finally consistent. These UI details are easy to spot in the included pictures with various lighting values. But they are available to most users outside of this product.Response and animation are a cut above their predecessors, and that should not be understated. I finally feel the Kindle is quick enough for my needs with digital reading. My 7th gen was abysmal. The 2018 version was slightly problematic. The newer page turn animation, however, was not to my liking, and I ended up sticking with the normal style. As a plus, the web browser is snappy and usable for those that need to quickly look something up on a search engine. Exiting in and out of menus is a breeze, and opening or downloading books was efficient. I still wish there was a download all option, so I will be downloading from the website instead.And speaking of default, the designers have made sure that this Kindle is ready to use without even touching a setting. They clearly invested a lot in understanding how people want their Kindle to look. I found almost all default options to be optimal. I added one step to boldness in fonts, and have toyed with the variable warmth quite a bit. Bookerly is a great font for reading, but there are obviously other options if you prefer. These things are basically as good as they need to be on this digital reader. More improvements with font selection could be possible, but are entirely superfluous to the current experience.Updating the firmware was painless for me past having to click no thanks for all the subscriptions Amazon wants to get you hooked on. No thanks. No issues with connections or anything of the sort. Charging works perfectly via USB-C, a far better connector than the micro version. Adding and subtracting to the library was fast and convenient.Aesthetics and materials are premium for the most part. Other than the aforementioned pinprick trail of adhesive, there were no outright imperfections that I can see. I don't really like the Oasis 3, but it's definitely similar to that version, with a better form factor.The leather case included with this bundle is what it is: completely overpriced but nearly mandatory for the perfect feel and weight. I can't stand the feel of the device without the included case. I highly recommend the bundle. The aesthetics look nice, and overall it's mostly the same as my last one. A bit easier to get in and out compared to 7th gen.At the heart of it all, this is still just another updated version of the Paperwhite. But it could be mandatory because it polishes the lighting and page turning to a degree that makes the old devices feel awkward. I don't see myself getting another one for a decade. And that leaves two questions remaining: How is the battery life, and is this worth the upgrade if you own the 2018 version...Battery life seems improved. I wouldn't call it all that great on full brightness, but it's definitely an upgrade from anything before. Battery life is critical, I have run into few issues with my normal settings. Right now, I can see that it drains decently fast on max brightness, but it also has an array of 17 LEDs lighting it. On lower brightness, it appears to be very conservative with battery life, much the same as last time but probably better. It's tough to say when you are comparing older batteries to newer ones. This will be an ongoing process to be updated in the review every now and then. On the lowest brightness it is off of course, for those that prefer the older Kindle experience and extended usage without a charge. This produces a charge that lasts a very long time.For me I see no reason to keep Wi-Fi on, and the complaints about that particular setting, coming from 2018, seem slightly obtuse. Shut it off when your library is downloaded. Problem solved. With full brightness, you aren't going to get a ton of life, but I also recommend against full brightness as it doesn't really resemble paper at that point. On medium settings, which I prefer, battery life seems completely acceptable and better than before.If you are currently using a device below the Paperwhite 2018, then definitely you could think about an upgrade if you are in the market for a new E-Reader. I cannot overstate how much better this is than my 7th gen. I rarely even used that model, and I will definitely be clocking in some time with this one due to the screen and response time. It's a huge motivating factor to actually take out my Kindle now. Previous versions do not match up, and this is the first time I can say I am impressed by a Kindle.Coming from 2018, I would say this is a fairly huge upgrade, and most will want to eventually make the change. The screen is too versatile to pass up, and the faster response time basically nails the previous version in its coffin. I don't think an immediate upgrade is necessary, but most will want this as their baseline going forward. The 2018 version has too many issues, and this fixes most of them.Economically, this might not be an option for many. To somewhat help out, you definitely will want to get this in the bundle with the leather case, which I included a picture of at the bottom. It's a nice case, way too expensive by itself, and kind of mandatory in my experience. The bundle also includes a trade-in option. Definitely DO NOT buy the case separately. No need to give Amazon any more of your money than necessary.Outside of that you can be sure I will remain critical of this device. If anything goes wrong, becomes damaged or defective, I will immediately add that info to my review. No shilling is allowed here. Freezes have gone completely away as of the recent firmware update in 1.14.1.1.For those on the fence, it is best to wait a few months to see how things turn out. For now, I enjoy the device and have only a few issues. Going forward I hope to actually use a Kindle consistently for the first time. If I rated the Paperwhite 2018 one star, then this one is around four stars. A worthy upgrade for anybody in the market. Will it replace my physical collection? Never. Paper lives on forever."A beggar's book outworths a noble's blood."

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: Love my Kindle Paperwhite!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 18, 2023
options: Color: Agave Green | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I love having a Kindle Paperwhite! I was gifted this for my birthday and love it so much!My only complaint is the flashing white every couple of pages when set to dark mode, and the flashing black every few pages when in standard mode. It’s pretty dang jarring when reading in a dark, quiet room to have the screen flash white.I turned the page refresh button on & off & restarted my Kindle which luckily changed the flashing from every single page turn, to every few pages, but it’s still a “flaw” in this product that should be redesigned/fixed if possible. (Though from what I’ve read, it’s just how the tech is for Kindle.)I chose the Paperwhite over Oasis when reading reviews for the Oasis. Seems like a better buy but I’ll have to check out to see if the page lighting up in dark mode is a feature with Kindle Oasis too.Overall I am very happy with my Kindle Paperwhite. It’s radically improved my sleep cycles & quality of sleep. Now instead of scrolling on my phone at night, I’ve got my Paperwhite which is easy on my eyes. Reading my kindle on my phone still fatigued my eyes even in warm tone with dark background.I’m also pleased with how big the font can get. I’ve got Diabetic retinopathy & am blind in one eye with huge vision loss/blurry vision in the other eye. The big writing is so helpful for me to be able to still read.Even with the jarring, flashing light every couple of pages with this model, I would still rather have a Kindle than not.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: Signature vs Paperwhite: Observations from Owning Both
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 19, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I own the 11th Gen (newest model 2022) standard Kindle Paperwhite and the Signature Paperwhite. I love them both. If dough is not the issue, I would buy the Signature model for fifty bucks more. Here’s some of my particular findings in use.Cases: Note that I do not like the Amazon cases because I don’t like folding over cover type cases; I prefer cases that simply help with holding the device.  I purchased the “MoKo Case for 6.8" Kindle Paperwhite (11th Generation-2021) and Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition, Ultra Clear Soft Flexible Transparent TPU Skin Bumper Back Cover Shell, Clear” from Amazon and it fits the Kindle ideally, and most importantly this case DOES go on the proprietary charging stand made by Anker and the charge does go through the case (that is, I do not need to remove the case to charge the Kindle in that charging stand).Battery: Amazon states that the Kindle 11th gen will hold a charge for 10 weeks, when used at limited brightness for 90 minutes a day (and a lot of other stipulations, like WiFi and Bluetooth off, etc). In reality, many may turn up the brightness, read more than 90 minutes, and Airplane mode on, or use other features that drain the battery faster (See audiobooks below). I have found that my battery drains faster than 10 weeks, but I am using the device with Airplane mode off, Wifi on, Bluetooth On. I do not like turning off wifi in particular because it MUST Be on to sync books between devices, and since I have two Kindle 11th gens, plus a MacBook, iPhone, iPad, and I read 5 books at a time simultaneously, I have no desire to turn wi-fi off.  Thus, having Qi charging is helpful…not mandatory but helpful.  Another BIG reason for the Qi charging is Audible audiobooks. I do listen to them through the Kindle itself, and the battery drains fairly quickly when listening to audiobooks.Memory Storage: The Kindle has 8 GB storage, but only 5.8 GB after their software OS.  The Signature Kindle has 32 GB storage, but only 28 GB after their software OS (there is slightly different software between the two models as the Signature supports more menu and charging features). So if you love downloaded “off-line” reading, and in particular if you enjoy having audiobooks in your downloaded library (they take much more storage than an e-book), the 32 GB is reassuring.Auto-light adjust: I can’t even detect that it’s doing anything, but if one rides a train daily to work and it passes through dark tunnels, this feature may be of benefit to you.Advertising free: Many forget the $20 value of the ad-free that is part of the Kindle Signature.  Even those that wouldn’t pony up for it on their own may enjoy it here as “icing on the cake” for the price difference.  I like seeing my own book cover on the sleep screen, and that is not possible with the “with ads” version. I thought I enjoyed the ads for editors choice books and book sales and stuff, but I much prefer the ad-free model.  And, little discussed fact, the ad-free version has one less swipe to get to your Library or current book every single time you turn on the Kindle. True!Dedicated Signature Charger Stand: I bought the Qi charging stand and like it greatly.  It does work with my “MoKo Case for 6.8" Kindle Paperwhite (11th Generation-2021) and the Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition, Ultra Clear Soft Flexible Transparent TPU Skin Bumper Back Cover Shell, Clear”., and charges through the case and the case fits the stand (but not quite as bump-proof as the Kindle without the case). I like that the stand sits quietly on my desk as I am working, or on my coffee table while I’m watching sports do I can read during commercials. I do not need to keep the AC cord attached to the stand at all times; sometimes I use the charger stand as simply a free-standing stand for either of my Kindles. I like that it can hold my Kindle 11th generation normal edition without Qi charging and I can read on it as an easel stand.  I feel the utility as an easel stand is underrated. Qi chargers in general are not free, and neither are easel stands, so coupling those two together, you get the price of this Anker model.  I find no issues with the size of the “wall wart” or the plug in the back of the stand. Some people complain with the charging stand that the white light indicator does not turn to another color, such as green, to indicate full charge.  A “work around” for this is to place the charging Kindle on the stand upside down; now the LED light at the bottom of the Kindle device itself, which does change color when fully charged, is face upward and easily seen. Frankly, there is no issue with simply assuming the Signature PW is charged after an hour or two. I like this stand much more than I thought I would.I’ve owned every Kindle since the first one! I use library Libby, and am an Audible and Kindle Unlimited subscribers. I guess you could say I’m a “power user”. I definitely prefer the Signature version, but both are good readers.  If I could change one thing about these Kindles, it would be to add a physical button like the Oasis. I realize that sounds outdated, but to reach and switch with the other hand, or reach thumb across screen to scrub, every page turn is a chore that is solved with an under-thumb button like Oasis. Additionally, the e-ink is good, but after two decades, one would think the text versus background contrast would be better…that is, darker text, whiter background. Instead, it remains darkest gray text in lightest gray background, not ideal.  Happy reading!

text: I recently took to reading on a Kindle for convenience and because we have tons of books and they just take up too much space. I have adjusted quickly and really like it but on the previous device I used, my eyes got tired from the brightness and whiteness of the screen. I'm also concerned about anything that could affect sleep and I can't definitively say the light did but I can say I've had fewer bad nights since switching to this device and maxing out the warm light setting ( this feature is a game changer!).  I can read longer without my eyes getting kind of watery and tired. My only tiny complaint is the increased size and weight but this is by no means a deal breaker and I'm already used to it (plus I got a case with elastic bands for your hands which helps with one handed reading). I also prefer that this doesn't have ads. Overall thrilled with this purchase and highly recommend if you're considering starting or upgrading your kindle experience. I also love that I can still read Library books through whatever service the Library uses as well. Finally, I have only had to charge once since I purchased a couple weeks ago so the battery life is no joke.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: So easy!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 11, 2023
options: Color: Agave Green | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I grew up being an avid reader as a child, which continued into adulthood.  After a couple of moves, with books packed away in boxes and other things that interfered with reading as often as I used to, I started thinking about the fact that I haven’t read anything significant in years.I realized how much I missed it, and how much time I was wasting with my “nose in my cell phone,” rather than a book!  With those things in mind, I started reading reviews on Amazon to compare the various versions of Kindle.I’m so happy with my new Kindle Paperwhite!  I love the fact that there is significant storage to hold books to read without depending on Wi-Fi.  The auto adjust feature for various lighting conditions is very handy.  For me, the very best part is that when I pick it up, I can immediately begin reading where I left off!  No more opening a book to two (2) side by side pages, and having to think about where I left off, or worse, having a bookmark fall out.  No more having to decide which book to take with me, which I wasn’t doing anyway… I can have them all with me, any time I want, wherever I am.  I can drop it in my purse any time I go out;  you never know when you’ll find a few minutes to read, instead of wasting that time playing on a cell phone!Years ago, I resisted switching over to a Kindle because I preferred the feel of a book in my hand, and the satisfaction of physically turning each page.As the years passed, while becoming accustomed to electronic devices being part of everyday life, I now realize that physically holding a book, and the tactile pleasure of turning pages was not being enjoyed because I was no longer reading at all.Getting my Kindle has shown me what’s most important:  It has given back to me the ability to enjoy reading again.I am particularly pleased with the features of the new Kindle Paperwhite, but for anyone with a more limited budget, I have no doubt that the less expensive versions can also bring the joy of reading back into anyone’s life if they experienced the same gradual straying away from daily reading that I did.  I highly recommend it!

text: If you saw something good written about this device, There ya go! I have had a number of Kindles over the years. I had a Touch, first. One of the grey ones, not a touch screen. It was fantastic! Enter the Paperwhite, I waited until the 2 before I got one. It was a game changer for reading. Having the light built in! I sadly lost it, and got a 3. I had always liked my 2 better. The 4 came along, and though I had lost a 3 to a storm while thru hiking, I still had insurance on it. BUT!!! The 5, 11th gen, Signature Edition came along... Well, another gripe I had with my 3v2, was that the 3 had a reduction in storage, and a smaller battery. That is why I liked my 2 better. Plus, the light was this greenish tinted colour I had preferred. BACK TO THE PWSE!What attracted me:+++ MUCHO storage!+++ Water resistance (I know the 4 had it, but remember, I had skipped)+++ USB C - Long over due (many other companies are still guilty of this (Apple, I am pointing at you)+++ Battery life CLAIMS - they were merely Amazon statements at this point. Now, I have not known  claims, by companies in this department to be typically truthful, beyond "lab conditions". The battery  life lived up to it!+++ BIGGER SCREEEN!!! I knew I would love it, when I saw one next to a 4/3/2/1 sized model, I was sold.Things that I didn't think I cared about but seemed like they could be neat:+++ Adjustable lighting - I like it much more than I thought I would! It has never been perfect on any  device by any company, and it isn't here. But, it does learn, and it does well. It definitely adds value+++ Warm lighting - Now this one, I though "woopidy doooooooo" But, after actually experiencing it, it is  something I LOVE, and would NOT give up! It is a WOOO HOOOOOO!!!!Something I thought I wanted, but only used it once to see if it worked:+++ Wireless charging. Although I like this on other devices, on my PWSE, the case I went with doesn't  allow for it. But, I really don't care. the USB C is readily available as most of my other devices use it.  And, it charges up in an hour or less. As I only charge it between 3 - 7 weeks at a time, and I have a  charger by my bed, it is no inconvenience to charge it that way. Some people do love it for theirs  though. Not at all anything to with Amazon or the Paperwhite, just my personal experience. It's there  should I ever change my mind, I suppose.As I have had this device since January of 2022, I can say without a doubt that it has met every expectation, and definitely deserves the high rating it maintains in reviews.

text: So to start I was very hesitant to buy. I love the smell and feel of a book & paper in hand. product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: Kindle App vs Actual Kindle?
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2023
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: Since 2016 I have been reading exclusively via the kindle app on whichever 8” fire tablet was available that year and had few complaints. Last week my tablet stopped connecting to wifi so it was time to replace it. I spent an entire day reading Kindle Paperwhite reviews and weighing it against getting a new 8” fire tablet. Obviously I went with the Kindle Paperwhite and here is my TL;DR: aside from the vastly superior battery life and water proofing, the Kindle app on a tablet is much better than the actual Kindle.First a difference I expected: the kindle app displayed all my books in color, obviously the Kindle Paperwhite is black and white. I didn’t think it would bother me but I do miss seeing all my colorful books in my library.The rest of the cons:The Paperwhite is SO SO SLOW compared to the app. When you tap to turn the page there is a slight delay and it often flashes while turning. Pressing the screen on/off button takes a few seconds to work, and navigating the store and your library is a MESS. I figured the actual kindle would be quicker to navigate through since it only has one job but nope. It’s so slow it’s almost a nightmare.The Paperwhite does not show you reading insights like the kindle app does. I have missed keeping up with my streak and earning awards/badges as I goThe Paperwhite is less reliable about connecting your book to GoodReads to show as “currently reading” than the app. I have read 3 books on the kindle since receiving it 4 days ago and I’ve had to manually add them all to my GoodReads profile despite the pop up at the beginning of the book that declares it is going to add it to “currently reading” on GoodReads.The Paperwhite’s “glare free” screen is not actually glare free. I often have to hold it at an angle to read the text. The screen is also way more prone to smudges than the tablet and because the e-ink is less crisp it makes it even fuzzier.Adding to that point—the display is far less crisp.  I’m near sighted so I typically do not wear my glasses to read, however, the far less crisp display almost makes me feel like I need the glasses on.Because the Paperwhite is in black and white only, you can obviously only highlight passages in one color. On the app there are 3 and I utilized them for different things (blue for important story points, pink for errors, and yellow for anything that made me laugh).The bookmark function on the Paperwhite is really annoying. You have to tap the upper right portion of the screen and then tap the plus sign to add the book mark. On the app you simply tap the upper right portion of the screen and it’s bookmarked. I lost a bunch of things I’d like to bookmark not realizing I needed to hit the plus sign.This last point is definitely just me being picky/finicky but I really hate that the screen doesn’t turn off. I don’t know why but it annoys me.These annoyances aren’t enough to want to go through the hassle of returning the Paperwhite to purchase a fire tablet but if I had the decision to make again, knowing what I know now, I probably would have purchased a new tablet instead.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: Hardware is great. Now improve the operating system.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I've liked and owned several Paperwhites because they are made for one thing: reading. Amazon's other tablets just don't appeal to me. Several months ago I traded up to the Signature Edition from a 2015 Paperwhite, and this new model resolves just about every hardware quibble I've ever had with previous versions. See reviews by others for highlights on physical improvements, including display, charging port, etc.While there have been definite improvements to the Paperwhite operating system over the years, interaction with it is still difficult when one wants to change display brightness, type size, etc. Some changes, typeface size controls for example, don't feel like improvements, they mostly seem more difficult. Weirdly, once one has figured out the correct way to get where one wants to go within the controls, the process is convoluted enough that it doesn't stick in the brain, and one must rediscover it again later. Overall, the OS is still clunky in several important places.There's also a bug that has been present for ages and seemingly never addressed: the progress indicator disappears from the display quite frequently. It seems the theme switches on its own from the default to something off the rails, or the progress indicator just disappears from the default theme settings, I'm not sure. I work around this by creating a custom theme that mimics my default settings, then deleting every other theme option except for default (I'm fearful of what might happen if I delete it). When the progress indicator disappears, I open themes and switch from whichever theme is currently selected to the other, default or custom.In some ways the Paperwhite is a pretty mature product at this point, but there is still plenty of room for improvement within the operating system. Maybe a full, ground-up  rewrite of the OS is in order?

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: So close, but so far away from perfection
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I have mixed feelings about this product and about the entire Kindle ecosystem. There is no doubt that this is the only game in town; none of the others (nook, sony, kobo) give anything close to the total ecosystem experience of Amazon kindle. The number of books, features on the devices, hardware and software offered etc. Amazon has clearly put a lot of thought into this, as book selling is their claim to fame. However, taking this into account I am at disbelief why, coming so close to perfection, they stopped where they did. There are clearly some serious shortcomings with the  entire setup:1. Kindle Paperwhite itself: capacitive screen that gets dirty, many of the books are not rendered correctly,  Abysmal translation, dictionary options. For gods sakes how awful is Bing at translation! No buttons to turn pages. Device restarts(crashes) once in a while when too many books loaded etc.2. Kindle for PC. Must've been programmed in late 90's and left like that. What a piece of cr@p clunky application. Right click menu is buggy. Only limited support for dictionaries/translation.3. Kindle for smartphone. Somewhat better, but has many of the problems such as rendering of books correctly.Additionally:WhisperSync not working correctly. I often have to swipe to get to the latest read page between devices.And if I switch between books the latest one isn't being opened.There is also Amazon cloudreader where you can read books in the browser, but you can only read Amazon's own books, not your own pdf or epub files.Getting books onto the device:This is a mess as well. There are three options:1. Email. Your kindle comes with a unique email address and you can send your ebooks there. This is ancient method of file transfer, but it's the only one that works reliably with Kindle. Meaning whatever you send will be properly formatted and will show up on your kindle.2. WebUI upload. You can drag and drop files into your browser(after logging into your account) and they will be transferred to your library. They however will NOT be formatted. If you attempt to transfer pdf/djvu it'll just show up like that and will be impossible to read.3. Sideloading. You can connect kindle via usb cable to pc and drag/drop files onto it. Same problem as with #2. above. It'll transfer the files, but will not format them properly.This brings me to the last point. Kindle claims to support many formats, but realistically if you want a comfortable reading experience you needs to get one of the ebook formats, such as epub or asw3. Anything else, such as pdf/djvu, will be a mess and impossible to read.Overall it's a mixed experience and I wish Amazon would finish the job by this point (after all this is 11th iteration of the device). It's the only game in town, so in many ways people have no were to go. But faults are many and certainly other options should be considered.

The Kindle Signature has become the perfect upgrade for me.I LOVE the wireless charging.  No need to buy the recommended Anker-made-for-Amazon 10 w charger - I bought the new Anker 315 10 w rapid charger for 10.00 plus tax from Amazon and it works flawlessly. So, to me, these criticisms are not things that bother me - or get at all in the way of my enjoyment of the Signature.I also do very much like the new USB-C charging port.  It adds a new, updated feature to the Kindle family.The Kindle is such a terrific device for us reading enthusiasts - IMHO, this one with the larger, higher resolution screen, incredible battery life, wireless charging, no ads, largest storage of all Kindkes is the bomb - especially with the Amazon Kindle trade in policy and 20% discount on the Signature.Couldn’t be happier with my decision. product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: Uncomfortable and a little overrated when compared to an older model
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I'm coming from a 7th generation Paperwhite that's held up well over time. It's obviously slower than the Signature, and the battery has a little less staying power than in the past, but otherwise my 7th generation is great and a pleasure to read from. It's so great, in fact, that I have struggled to commit to this newer model since I got it a few months ago. The biggest upgrades with it are speed, wireless dock charging, USB-C standardization, and the page warmth functionality. The biggest downside is worse ergonomics if you have smaller hands and particular layout preferences.THE SIGNATURE IS KIND OF UNCOMFORTABLE TO USEBy far, my biggest complaint is the Kindle Signature is physically uncomfortable for me to use. If you've got large hands, you might be fine, but if you've got smaller hands, I think the potential for discomfort is higher. For me, the Signature is *just* large enough that it's awkward to hold one-handed and even causes me some pain to do so for extended periods, and it's *just* small enough that it feels awkward in a different way to hold with two hands. As someone who already widens margins and linespacing, I'm *personally* not looking for a larger viewing space (just an e-ink display), but I'll tolerate it...provided it doesn't ruin comfort. Here, it comes close to ruining it.Adding to the frustration is how thin and slick the device is. Let's start with the thinness. The idea that thinner is better is coming from the phone market, but readers are (somewhat) looking to replace the physical experience of holding a book, which is *not* a thin object and is also bigger than a phone. Holding the Signature, I get marks on my hands, especially when propping my hand along the edge while lying down and reading on my side. With my 7th generation, this never happens because, while it is thin, it is not super thin; it's got a soft, chunky edge that is gentle on the hands.A CASE IS A MUSTJust as the device's thinness seems to be coming from the phone market, so, too, does the device's slick back. The back of the Signature is so slick that I honestly think it's a ploy to get you to buy an official case to make it more usable—which then makes the device heavier to use. This thing slides like crazy on anything remotely soft, which, when coupled with the thin edge, makes for very annoying reading in certain positions.Between this and the fact that the touch screen is no longer semi-protected by a beveled frame edge, I would think this version of the Kindle is much more susceptible to damage if you drop it or stuff it into a zippered pouch. I've had two other Kindles and never bought a case for them because, provided you tucked them in a soft space/bag, they were fine. With the Signature, I feel I need a case just to use the e-reader comfortably at all.I WANT AN E-READER, NOT A TABLETRemember how I said there's no longer a beveled frame edge? There are pros and cons to that. The pro is that it makes for a smoother swiping experience. The con is that I think it exists mainly because the Signature is trying to be both a tablet and an e-reader. The problem with this, of course, is that if you're buying a tablet, you don't want an e-ink display, and if you're buying an e-ink display, you're consciously avoiding a tablet for your reading experience. I don't know which features are driving the Kindle more toward a tablet-like experience, but I'm skeptical.I could be way off base, but auto-adjusting light and dark mode are the features I suspect they've traded the most for, and they're just not worth it. It's not that hard to adjust brightness and never has been. And an e-ink dark mode just isn't as good as a backlit LED dark mode. It literally can't be because of how an e-ink display works. I gave this mode a shot, but I can't imagine using it, not when the page warmth functionality helps achieve similar comfort in low light conditions while looking a lot more natural.EXPECT A GLAREWhatever is driving the more tablet-like feel, there is a big cost, and it comes most of all in the form of an exposed screen and glare. Take a look at my pics of the 7th generation versus the Signature. I know which I'd rather have in the sun or even in a room with certain lighting/bulbs.The other cost is to the touch surface itself. Before buying, I did see people complaining about how the Signature picks up fingerprints easily. I didn't think much of it. But those negative comments are right. It's noticeable.VERDICTI don't *hate* the Signature, but as far as an upgrade goes...it doesn't feel like much of one. In several ways, it feels like a downgrade, at least for me. I'm an avid enough reader that I ultimately decided to keep both devices, but I'm sort of annoyed.

text: My Kindle Paperwhite 7th gen (released 2015), was still working fine when I upgraded to this. I have been waiting for the USB - C Kindle, and I'm now officially micro-usb free. I traded in and paid the extra to get the wireless charging so that, when this Kindle lasts many years to come, I can still use it when we're someday cable-free entirely.At a high level, this Kindle is a terrific device. Until color Kindles come out some day years from now, it's going to be perfect for reading use. It's lightweight and a pleasure for me to use with one or two hands. All my minor complaints aside, I truly love this device and use it daily. I have no complaints with regard to my daily use. If you have the Kindle paperwhite I had before, it's not worth upgrading unless you want to treat yourself. I have no regrets about the purchase, as I wanted to treat myself. If you don't have a Kindle, this is the best, and you will enjoy it.The reasons I upgraded:-Larger screen. Nice, not necessary but apprecated-Dark mode. Old generations didn't have this (thanks, Amazon, for artificially limiting older generations' software)-USB-C. I was way too excited about this, but I stand by it.I was concerned that the flush glass screen would be worse than my old paperwhite's recessed screen. It is, but not noticeably so, which I'm pleasantly surprised to say. It's less paper-y than the old Kindles, but makes the Kindle look very clean and crisp. It's plenty responsive, and there's still enough bezel to hold it without touching the screen.It also has the same ppi (Pixels per inch) of my 2015 Kindle, and the new screen type makes it less clear because of the layers. I was concerned about that too, but it's not noticeable.Side-loading books is still very easy with new versions of Calibre.Dark mode is great for reading in bed with the lights off without bothering a partner next to you in bed. I upgraded primarily for the dark mode, as regular mode is too bright for me when I'm trying to go to sleep (same for real books with a reading light).It wirelessly charges on both of my phone chargers, one of which is one of the stand-style chargers (like the Amazon-branded Kindle one). I'm a little surprised that the larger Kindle still works on my phone's charging stand, and it is an excellent little surprise.A couple other notes for you future owners:-Don't buy the Amazon-branded cases for this generation. They're a rip-off and poorly designed this generation. There are many generic cases that work just as well, such as Ayotu's. I use that case for when I travel with the Kindle in a bag.-Don't buy the Amazon-branded USB wall adapters. They're ridiculously overpriced, and their maximum wattage is below the Kindle's maximum charging wattage. Amazon scam.-Don't buy the Amazon Kindle charging stand. It's got a weird proprietary cable to hook into the wall. You're better off getting one flat wireless charging pad, as pretty soon (if you're not already there), your phone, earbuds, and Kindle will all charge wirelessly, and a flat pad will be able to fit all of them. How often will you really need to charge your Kindle, anyways?-I got a Harris Tweed sleeve from SarahJayneDesi9ns on Etsy, and highly recommend it. It's beautiful.Other miscellaneous gripes:-It's a ripoff that Amazon charges for you to remove ads from a product you bought, but that's not relevant to this version, as there is no ad version with wireless charging.-It's a ripoff that I couldn't have dark mode on my old paperwhite. It's black and white. It's not too difficult to push a software update to it to make it white and black. They just wanted me to upgrade (and it worked). Buying this product supports that corporate mentality.-The screen is the same ppi and slightly blurrier than my 2015 Kindle.-To reiterate, the main upgrades are a charging port that Android phones have used since 2008 and a software update that they wouldn't let my 2015 Kindle have.I still love this Kindle and will use it daily for years to come. For being a mainstream product, I really appreciate Kindles' longevity, and I truly hope this one will last for years like the previous generations have.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: My 4th Paperwhite: REALLY!??
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: For those of you who aren’t up to reading this long saga, here is my best advice:  DO NOT BUY A PAPERWHITE! Here’s how I came to this conclusion:I received Paperwhite Signature edition with upgraded memory for Christmas 2021. I admit, at first I (mostly) loved it. It replaced my Voyage, which I LOVED, but had slowed way down, downloading had become so difficult, downloading new books often failed. The speed of my new Paperwhite was fabulous (at first). I loved some of the UI’s changes.I absolutely HATE being forced to deal with a grid of book covers that are nearly impossible to read! Yes, a list is a choice for the library page, but even that uses up valuable space with— you guessed it— book covers. I also dislike the fact that the Home page mostly advertises books. Yes, I know there are many more books available, but if I want to browse, I’ll go to the Store. Don’t use space on a kindle I (well, my son) paid for!  Use your own space, I.e., the StoreI like having the choice to list titles by series. This can be convenient, especially since each title’s order is listed. However, this aside, the so-called organization of all kindles I have had (early kindle, Voyage, and now Paperwhite) is laughable. I rely heavily on collections. Unfortunately, it only allows one level of differentiation within a collection, therefore no way to identify the sequence of titles within a series. Why couldn’t the series feature be available within a collection?As it is, I choose the title I wish to read next in a collection, then must go to the series featured in my library. Come on! And choosing my next book from a listing of ALL my 1000+ titles— with no differentiation other than alphabetically by author, title (don’t make me laugh!) or “recently,” is impossible.I also like having control over brightness and warmth of the screen. I really like being able to simply set my kindle on its charger. Unlike others, I’ve had little trouble with it charging, even with the cover in place (as long as I don’t place it upside down!)I very much appreciate the developers’  putting the clock back at the top of each page I’m reading. It was there in my Voyage— but NOT my first PaperWhite. It was available by clicking at the top; but this required interrupting my book. Without a clock in view, I tend to lose track of time when I’m reading. So I was happy to see it back at the top of the page when I received my most recent PaperWhite.Right. My biggest issue by far is that I just received my FOURTH PaperWhite in less than a year! The first one— the one I received from my wonderful son last year— just froze in a very few weeks. It wouldn’t do anything. A hard reset didn’t help. So I called Amazon. The customer service representative was very nice. He asked me to take certain actions, all of which I’d tried based on recommendations from YouTubers, but he wanted me to try again. So I did. Didn’t help. Then he said, “No problem. I’ll. send you a new one “ and he did. Which was great, but I must confess, I saw it as a problem. I spent days downloading my extensive library— about a thousand at that time.So I received my SECOND PaperWhite, spent days downloading everything again (which meant NOT reading on it). And a few weeks after that, you guessed it, it froze.  Rinse, repeat. I received my THIRD PaperWhite. Same deal. Except this time when I called Amazon, the rep taught me to do a variation of a hard reset. Basically, he told me to hold the bottom button through many resets,  approximately 10), without releasing it. And if it doesn’t work at first, try again. It worked!I thought that was great!  And every few weeks, it froze again, and I would do multiple resets, and it worked. UNTIL several days ago. This time, it didn’t freeze out of the blue. Instead, various things failed to work. At first, just the “deals” page didn’t display. Then it wouldn’t access “Settings.”  I did a hard reset (not multiples as above), but nothing seemed to change. More failures, but I did have access to my library — until it refused to open any book (at this point, I have 1200+. Have you SEEN all the free books available? Some of them are good. I’ve found several “favorite” authors that way.)I had called Amazon with the first issue, and was just waiting for the new one. BTW, I’m pretty sure all these replacements are “refurbished,” not new.  I REALLY wish that I had accepted a refund, offered after the first two quit working. I suspect this pattern will continue, with me doing very hard resets to keep this PaperWhite limping along, until the warranty runs out and I end up with a frozen PaperWhite, and depending on my old Voyage to read my e-books.Honestly, I prefer hardcovers.  However, I have spinal damage and have been totally disabled 20+ years. I have issues holding hardcovers, and the problem is getting worse. I’ve even begun replacing some of my many, many paper books with kindle editions. It is much easier for me to read for hours on end holding a kindle, due to their smaller, lighter size. So I’ve been moving to kindles.I hoped initially that there was a software problem, and the developers would be able to fix it, and download it in an update. This is a new version, so that would be understandable. But it hasn’t happened, so I’ve come to believe this is an integral hardware issue that can’t be rectified until the next rebuild.My advice is simply DON’T BUY A PAPERWHITE!!! They are deeply, intrinsically flawed in this version. I wish Voyages were still supported, and available. It had minor issues, mostly related to my personal preferences, but overall was a great edition. So maybe try an Oasis, though personally, I’m not sold on its shape. Personally, as others have mentioned, I want an e-reader, not a tablet. (I have a tablet, but I don’t like reading books on it.) My son has tried to convert me to Audible, but I tried it, didn’t like it. I may be forced to “read” with Audible eventually, though.Sorry for the length of this review. Thank you to those who’ve made it to the end! Good luck finding the right fit for you.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: Almost perfect, but no page turn buttons
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2021
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: Let me start by saying this is my 4th overall Kindle e-reader, including owning the 4th generation Paperwhite and the Oasis 3rd generation. I have fallen in love with e-readers and reading again because of the Kindle line and this model is almost perfect.Starting with the screen, it is now 6.8”, up from 6” from the previous model. Personally, I liked the smaller form factor of the prior version, but with the bigger size, you do get more words per line. I don’t normally read books with lots of graphics, but I’m sure that would be an improvement as well. The one major feature that I loved on my Oasis was the warm lighting at night and now, that is available on the Paperwhite line. Great addition! The screen is the same 300 ppi as before and the text is sharp. Another addition to the Signature Paperwhite is an auto-brightness feature. Personally, I never used it on my Oasis and probably won’t on this one either. However, I have no complaints about the screen, it is near-perfect for an e-reader.Amazon finally updated the Kindles for USB-C charging! Personally, that should have been added in the previous generations, but it's here now. Finally, I don’t have to carry around an extra Micro USB cord just for my Kindle. In addition to that, the Signature Paperwhite also includes wireless charging. I first thought that feature was a bit hokey, but after using it on my iPhone and Kindle Fire HD 8”, it is nice to have, even if you don’t normally charge that way.One feature that Amazon really didn’t mention too much about was that they surely updated the processor in this model. It is fast, well, fast for an e-reader :) In my prior Paperwhite, sometimes I’d tap the screen for a page turn and nothing would happen, so I would tap it again, only to have it then turn 2 pages. The Paperwhite Signature Edition is very responsive and there is very little to no lag time, which is more like the Oasis line. Very nice!Personally, I much prefer the form factor of the Paperwhite over the Oasis’ asymmetrical design. I just never really liked it and although I don’t care that Amazon continues to sell them, I wanted to see a more premium version in the standard form factor, like the prior Kindle Voyage, since retired, and it here in the Paperwhite Signature Edition…ALMOST….There is one MAJOR issue I have and that is that Amazon didn’t include page turn buttons on this model. I of course knew this before purchasing, but nonetheless, I feel it deserves mentioning. I think that Amazon would have hit a home run out of the ballpark had they included page turn buttons, but apparently, they want to keep that feature (for now) on their premium Oasis line. And because Amazon choose to exclude page turn buttons, I only gave this model 4 stars.If you’re new to e-readers, although this is a fantastic option, if you don’t care about auto-brightness, wireless charging, or unless you absolutely need 32 GB of storage (most don’t for just regular books, audio books and graphics novels are an exception), consider the regular 11th generation Paperwhite. It’s $50 less and you still get the same large screen and warm lighting. Or better yet, while they are still available, get the 10th generation Paperwhite. As of this writing, I saw them on sale for $84.99, That’s a steal for that model.Finally, one gripe I have is that Amazon did not include the latest version of their Kindle software. I went to Amazons site to manually run the update and it is not listed there either. I have it on my Oasis and it is a nicer layout. I am sure it will be available at some point in the future, but it is perplexing that Amazon would create an update and then a month later, release a new Kindle without the ability to update it.Overall, I do recommend the Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition, if you have a few extra bucks for the features. But they aren’t a must have to be honest, and for most people, the regular Paperwhite will be more than sufficient.UPDATE 11/5/2021The latest software update was released a couple of days ago and I was able to update it. I wanted to comment of a couple of other complaints people had. First, the fact that this is only available in wi-fi. Personally, I thought the 3G/4G models were a bit overkill. I mean, how hard is it to download a book at home before you leave? Or for that matter, find a wi-if hotspot somewhere? I think most people are not going to miss that feature, especially since it was a pricey upgrade anyway. Secondly, the fact the power button is on the bottom of the unit. This has been there for quite a few generations now and on the prior models I’ve owned. It personally has never been a problem for me. Yes, I’d prefer that it was on top, but I’ve never accidentally pressed it while reading. And on this new model, the button itself does require a bit of force to depress, so I really can’t see too many people hitting it by mistake and actually turning the device off. Finally with the screen, well, my prior comment stands. It really is nice. Not sure how some can feel it is a downgrade. The lighting is very uniform when reading at night and there are no dead spots. Furthermore, the contrast ratio seems higher, resulting in deeper blacks and whiter whites.

text: This is my 6th Kindle although Amazon has labeled it as my 4th.  My last Kindle (#5) purchased in 2019 works just fine.  I bought this because of wireless charging, how long the charge lasts and it is a teensy bit larger.  I read my Kindle for at least an hour every day.  I take it with me wherever I go.  I love my Kindle.  I have no idea why Amazon skipped a number between 3 and 5--and now made up for it in 2023.  This caused issues as the program still listed #5 as my default Kindle, rather than the new #4 Kindle.  At any rate --it has the same features pretty much as my 2019 Paperwhite except for the features mentioned.  The highly sensitive touch screen drives me crazy tho--the slightest, or accidental touch changes the page, sometimes more than one page and I have to figure out where I am.  There is an option to disable the touchscreen temporarily--- however you cannot get to anything else when you do that. You can however still read the book and turn pages by swiping.  It is easy to get the touchscreen back by quickly pressing the power button.  Since I specifically bought it in the bundle to get the compatible charger I am very disappointed that the charger will not arrive until mid March.  What is up with that?  By the way--the main reason I have bought so many is not because they went bad (well except for the first one) but because I wanted a different version.  Would I recommend it?  Yes if your first Kindle, or if your old Kindle is dying--or you want the extra bells and whistles.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: A deeply-flawed UI drags this down (Updated)
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: My first Kindle was the 2nd edition with keyboard and joystick. I've owned many since, my favorite being the Voyage. When that one got a scratch on the screen, I decided it was time to upgrade and got the Signature Edition of the Paperwhite. While there are many good things about this model, the UI and certain policies by Amazon have drastically harmed the usability of this reader.First off, visibility of the screen is quite nice when reading. The ability to adjust the warmth of the light is very welcome. The slightly larger screen than the Voyage means more text can fit on the screen, though it does weigh a little more and is larger. You feel the difference in your hand when holding it for longer periods (which is usually the result of average reading sessions). Still, that's all expected when using something slightly larger. While reading, it's a very nice experience.That nice experience disappears outside of reading though. If you are more than a casual reader and have been building a library of ebooks, you'll find the experience very lacking, especially as you get older. There is a fact about growing older... your eyesight changes. Even if you don't need glasses for clarity, your ability to see contrast diminishes as you get older. Greyscale images are more difficult to read. The new UI lists books in a "cover view" where you see a grid of thumbnail images of the cover of the books in your library. Trying to read the titles of the books from a smaller greyscale image of the cover is difficult. A simple listing would be better. The UI does offer a simple listing, but when you choose to view your listing in this manner, you then see one long listing of all of the books on your kindle and do NOT see them grouped by Collections. The larger your library, the more books you have to scroll through. Collections in this view become worthless, forcing you to see your entire library. You have three different choices then, all of which are cumbersome. You can: 1) Scroll through a long listing of ALL of your books; 2) Scroll through just a Collection and see your books by images of their covers (harder to read with 55+ eyes); or 3) Keep switching views as you move in and out of collections. It's frustrating, and Amazon gives no way to offer feedback, forcing you to accept what they choose without comment.A recent decision by Amazon groups graphic novels and comics as part of your Kindle library. If you use their Comixology service to buy and read digital comics and graphic novels, then all of those are also listed in your Kindle library, even though reading material like that on an e-ink Kindle is probably the last thing you'll want to do. Most fans of graphic novels either read them on color devices where the artwork can be appreciated. You have to rely on filters to get rid of those listings.While many people may not consider the UI changes to be too impacting, the more books you have and the older you are increase the difficulty level. Having been buying books since the 2nd Edition Kindle, I have a library of over 1,500 books. That's a lot to sort through when I want to reread one, and my 62-year-old eyes don't handle the greyscale images well. It's a very unpleasant experience until I actually find the book and open it.On more thing... I suspect the wireless charger is somewhat temperamental. I have wireless charging pads in my home, and my phone (which is in a case) happily charges on them. The Kindle won't charge on any of them while it's in a case. Removing it from the case for charging is extremely cumbersome, so wireless charging is non-functional for me. The thickness of the case isn't any more than what's on my phone, so I suspect the kindle is fussier about being in closer contact with the pad, which is a shame.---Update 24/08/2022---I added an additional star to the review because I just received a phone call from the Kindle team regarding the issues I brought up in my review. We discussed them and the development team is being given a recording of all that I said so they can improve the UI experience (fingers crossed!). It's a good thing the team checks what's said in reviews and followis up with users who are unhappy, so I bumped up my review from two stars to three. I'll also modify the review and score to reflect future updates to the UI since it's only fair to rate the device on what the customer is going to receive when they buy one.

text: I want to start by saying I've been using Kindle Fires for years and have always liked them but they wore out pretty fast and I decided I'd finally get the Kindle Paperwhite. title: First Time Kindle User. Pretty Good...but not Great.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on June 8, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I have been using e-ink eReaders for over a decade, all of them Barnes & Noble's NOOK eReaders. The Kindle is new to me. I was drawn to the Amazon Kindle because of multi-language support, dictionaries and Audible syncing. Here are my takeaways on why it's a pretty good but not great device:Pros:1. Languages - Kindles have multiple language dictionaries based on books you may download to your library. For me, that's the Japanese-English dictionary when reading! It has made reading my more difficult novels a breeze. Unfortunately, this doesn't include Turkic languages.2. Vocabulary Builder - This is a great tool for students as well as the avid reader who loves learning.3. Charging - The Signature Edition has wireless charging, which wasn't something I actually cared about, but I have used it nearly every day because it's very convenient and it works even with the Amazon Kindle cover.4. Cover - The Amazon Kindle fabric cover has magnets that keep the cover closed, so I don't need extra latches, straps or hooks. I also like that it wakes the device when I open it!5. Waterproof - Because life happens.6. Library Book Borrowing - The second best experience for borrowing eBooks from your local public library.Cons:1. Screen - The finish of the touch screen and black bezel are extremely prone to fingerprints. It makes already slightly fuzzy e-ink text more difficult to read. In comparison to a 2015 Nook GlowLight that also boasts 300 dpi, the text on the 2021 Kindle Paperwhite occasionally looks smudged when the frontlight is on. Compared to the 2021 Barnes & Noble Nook GlowLight 4, also with 300 dpi, the Kindle Paperwhite looks sharper with the frontlight on, but less clear when off because of the screen's propensity to smudge up. I clean the display every time before and after use, but since one must use the touch screen to use the device, it cannot be helped. Perhaps a screen protector is best advised for the 2021 Kindle Paperwhite?2. Current Software - The software versions 15.4.x are cluttered. Since updating to this version, I have had glitches of unresponsive screens or blank screens requiring me to restart the device. Keeping it in Airplane mode has alleviated this issue. If you want to use the device for Wi-Fi or Whispersync, too bad. Also, why is the "From Your Library" font different from the entire OS? It looks out of place.3. Home Screen Ads - After the 15.4 software update, the new design of the home screen is nearly 60% books advertised by Amazon. I avoid the home screen now. Clearly I have a different definition of what constitutes an advertisement than Amazon.4. Navigation - Compared to the Nook or Kobo eReaders, the Kindle Paperwhite 11th gen takes 2-3 taps for what I used to do in 1 tap. Examples: While reading a book, you want to go back to the library: tap screen at top middle to bring up the menu > tap Library (2 taps vs 1 tap on NOOK device-dedicated home button). Bookmarking on Kindle requires 2 or 3 taps depending--1 tap on Nook. While reading a book, turning on the frontlight can take an astounding FOUR taps (touch top of screen, select drop down menu, select brightness, tap outside the menu to close it and/or tap in little remaining space to return to book); all of this is done with 1 long press on the Nook home button or a 1 sliding gesture on Kobo devices.5. Side-loaded Books - I have purchased EPUB eBooks from multiple eBook sellers, so I have had to convert them to an Amazon-friendly format, which I do not mind at all. However, Amazon removes the covers of side-loaded books once you connect to Wi-Fi and restart the device. If you want to keep your personal library with book covers on Kindle, you'll need to use third-party software and/or stay off Wi-Fi.6. Amazon Household / Device Sharing - I thought I would be able to set up Profiles for everyone in the house on the Kindle, similar to how we have used our Nook devices together. Unfortunately, Amazon Household/adult-user setup is completely different. You cannot share a Kindle device in the family using Profiles to mark individuals' reading places, making these very expensive dedicated devices. 32GB is a great size to share a big library, especially manga/graphic novels, too bad I cannot make a Profile for everyone.

title: Not perfect, but pretty close.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on December 5, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I want to start out by saying that I do enjoy this device very much, and it serves its intended purpose well. I've owned a few different iterations of the Paperwhite, and this one is definitely the most beautiful I've owned - after a returned unit due to dead pixels. The one I'm using, the replacement, still has weird pixels, but I live with it.Once you get past the tech nerd things, though, it's great. It's large by e-reader standards (I know the Scribe came out, and has a compelling value proposition, but man it's massive), is mostly uniformly lit, and runs VERY fast compared to previous generations. I have a few different iPads as well, and go to the Paperwhite for any text reading - it's just superior for that and shows the awesomeness of a single focused goal, in this case to replicate a book.This device will likely not be suitable for an all-rounder, however, and it makes no claims to that effect. It's nuclear-grade bookworm tech - all others need not apply.One last thing I want to highlight is that I've seen a lot of criticism of having both wireless charging and a USB C port on a device. Besides flexibility, it also provides redundancy. The charging port of a device is often the first thing to die - that addition makes this a ten year device instead of a five and is a killer addition.As far as drawbacks, really the only one is that Amazon still has a few issues to sort with their screens. It's not a perfect screen, and if you're looking you WILL find issues. Overall, though, it's far superior to the old ones, where you didn't have to look to find them.It's great, with some caveats.

options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: Deciding which Kindle I wanted was pretty easy… I wanted one that was water resistant, could be wirelessly charged, and would be easy on my eyes. I went with the Paperwhite Signature.PackagingThe packaging is very small, it’s just the Kindle and a charging cable.OnboardingWhen onboarding I was given two options - onboard on the device or via Amazon app, with a note indicating that the via app is faster. The screen told me what to do (open the app, go to this location and follow the flow. Onboarding took 5 minutes. I wasn’t confused at any point, I didn’t have any issues at all. I was even able to not only setup Wi-Fi on my new Kindle via the Amazon app, but also store my Wi-Fi password. I don’t know where it’s stored, maybe on the device or the cloud but it was convenient. Very good onboarding.Device UsabilityAbout me—Age: 34Occupation: Tech industryThe Kindle itself is incredibly user friendly- I’ve never used an eReader but it gave me 5 helpful tips of what I can do and then set me free. I was able to setup everything how I wanted and download my content. Additionally, it’s very intuitive. It noticed me looking up words by highlighting them and offered me to download an add-on called Word Wise- which I’ve never heard of. It allows me to see definitions above words. I played with it a bit but didn’t like it, it seems mostly geared toward young readers… it defined unacceptable as not acceptable. Even on the lowest setting I still saw the words I knew defined so I decided to continue to look up words individually. I really hate the slowness and lag when scrolling, but I’m of the assumption this is to conserve battery… and maybe it’s because I have the battery saver on but I value the longer battery life over the fancy animations.ManualThe device doesn’t come with a paper owners manual, but it’s pretty easy to figure out most things… and the manual is in the device itself and you could also google the question (as was my choice).AccessoriesI already knew using the cable to charge the device was not going to be my preference, so I ordered the wireless charger made for it and it works fantastic. I also ordered a case that had a hand strap in the back just because I feel like the device is very lightweight and when I put it in my purse I’d like the screen protected.All in all I love the Kindle. It’s very easy on my eyes, much easier to read than it was on the Kindle app on my iPhone.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: Truly Converted Me
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on July 14, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: For many years I have been a staunch believer that physical books were the only proper way to enjoy my favorite books. For years my wife gently suggested a kindle, to stop the incoming tide of books piling up on shelves and even under the bed. Well I finally decided to give one a shot, and I could not be happier. The paperwhite does an excellent job of mimicking the look of a real page and I have not experienced any eye fatigue at all while reading. The Signature edition is worth the extra cost in my opinion for the additional storage space, but also the auto adjusting back light. I did not think that feature would make much of a difference to me but has quickly become one of my favorite features as it allows me to keep reading without stopping to adjust brightness when going from inside to outside or if the lighting changes in the room I am sitting in. At night the subtle glow of the Kindle Paperwhite helps me with not falling asleep while reading, usually a constant struggle for me, but doesn't leave me restless like looking at my phone does. The battery life is phenomenal. I have been using mine for 2 weeks and still have 60% battery life remaining on my original charge. I have changed my physical book buying habits to exclusively my favorites that I want to display and collect, but my everyday reading is now done almost exclusively on the Paperwhite. The ease of access to it and all the books in my Kindle library has increased the amount I am reading and that is the best reason I can think of to make the switch if you are unsure.A few minor gripes that I have found would be, the touchscreen, the kindle store specifically on the kindle, and graphic novels/comics. The touchscreen isn't unresponsive, but occasionally it doesn't pick up my swipes the first input. Not regular enough to even be an annoyance honestly, but worth mentioning. I do not recommend navigating the kindle store on the Kindle Paperwhite. The kindle is not designed with browsing the store in mind, and as such is slow and downright clunky. Fortunately there is a simple solution, browse the kindle store on your phone then just hit send to kindle. It's super easy to do and your Kindle will start downloading automatically once it has access to Wifi. I typically browse on my phone for a new book while taking a break at work, and when I pick up my Kindle when I'm ready to read the book is already downloaded and waiting. Lastly, I would not recommend using the Paperwhite to read graphic novels/comics personally. Everything is obviously in black and white so you aren't getting the full impact of the illustrations. This one is more up to personal preference but I would prefer to read these in full color.To summarize my rambling; If you are considering making the switch to an e-reader, the Kindle Paperwhite should absolutely be your first choice. Excellent battery life, convenience, and ease of access that has revolutionized my daily reading habits.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: Great Reading Device
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on October 6, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: First time kindle buyer here! So let’s start with the good. The device itself is a really good size. It’s compact and light yet sturdy and pretty well made. The lighting/coloration is very easy on the eyes and doesn’t contrast harshly (something I was worried about with trying to read electronically versus a physical book). I’m quickly running out of room for bookshelves, so this gives me the option of purchasing physical copies of series that I really loved later down the road. I was extremely surprised at how quickly the titles downloaded. I live in a super rural area with slow (10ish mbps download speed via satellite) wifi. So taking this device on the go will be super easy and quick. Let’s also not forget about the price differences between kindle options and physical copies!Now, on to the “other”. I won’t say bad… yet. I’m still super new to this, so it might just be a user-adjustment period. I have noticed what I originally thought was a screen-change glitch. Specifically, when in the store screen selecting a title or opening a book. After doing a bit more research, it seems like this is a normal thing that happens with most (if not all) kindles. Again, not a terrible thing. There is some lag with the touch screen, but it’s neither a bad nor good thing. It’s just there, so be patient when selecting! I also had to use google a bit to figure out how to navigate the screens, turn pages, and power options. The device came with little to no instructions for use other than the initial set-up process. After a quick search, functionality is simple. Careful of the right side of the screen! The scroll bar feature can be a little bit of an issue initially. It’s not a smooth scroll like with a smart phone or computer; there’s  more of a solid block/screen/page scroll. Last, and likely most important, is battery life. I’ve seen mention of the batter life supposedly supporting several hours of not days of reading.
