product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: Knocking this down another star
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on August 27, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: This is an update from my original review.  Having heavily used my new Paperwhite for a couple of weeks now, I'm knocking this down to 3 stars since there are at least couple issues that are growing quite negatively on me.First, they REALLY need to fix the wake-on-cover-open feature with a setting to turn this function off.  I like that the magnet helps keep the cover closed, but I shouldn't have to buy another expensive cover without a magnet to avoid the annoying wake-on-open function.  I raised this issue in my original review, and the more I use the Kindle, the more I hate this "feature."  Assuming the hardware is designed properly, please release a firmware update to allow the user to turn this function ON or OFF.Second, I shouldn't have put up with a menu to rate every single document when I reach the end.  There must be an option in Settings to turn this OFF.  Also, when I "X-out" of the ratings page the whole page turns blank, then I need to tap the top to get a menu back and then tap again to get back to my library.  REALLY?!!  Who wrote the GUI requirements for the firmware?  Let me guess:  Must have been someone in Sales or Marketing :-(Original Review:  This is my 2nd e-Ink Kindle.  My first is a 3G/WiFi/Keyboard type from 2010.  While it's still in excellent shape and even has the original battery, cellular companies bailed from their 3G support a while ago, and sadly, just recently Amazon stopped supporting the Shop feature of this old unit, even on WiFi.  I'm holding onto it as a backup, as I can always upload docs via my computer, but since I do so much reading I decided to break down and buy the Paperwhite Signature edition bundle, which included a leather cover and wireless charging dock.I'm so used to my older keyboard-style Kindle that I was a little apprehensive switching to a touchcreen, but I was pleasantly surprised at the relative ease of navigation. Overall there is a lot to like about the new Signature edition, and I would have rated it at 5 stars, save for a few small annoyances:1. There must be a way to turn off the wake-on-open feature, triggered by the magnet within the front cover.  I realize some covers do not have a magnet and therefore won't trigger the wake function upon opening, but one should be able to enable/disable this feature in the Settings menu.  I like the magnet, as it helps keep the cover closed, but I don't always want the Kindle to wake up when opened.2. I am so used to the paging buttons on my old Kindle, I REALLY miss them!  One needs to be careful swiping left or right via the touchscreen, as sometimes a page may be skipped over.  As I get used to the touchscreen this seems to be occurring less often.  Not sure if a "Swipe Sensitivity" setting would help here or not, but may be a feature worth adding in the Settings menu.3. The power button on the bottom edge should be a slider-type, definitely NOT a push button!  My old Kindle has a spring-loaded slider along the bottom edge, with a fairly long throw, so I have never accidentally triggered it (at least that I can recall, that is).4. I would like to see a bit more control by the user on exactly what is displayed on the Home screen.  While I purchased the add-free version, I am a minimalist and do not want to see recommended books or a lot of clutter unless I turn this feature on.  Perhaps there is a way to customize the Home screen and turn this feature off but I simply haven't figured it out yet, so this review may be updated at a later time.

text: I have owned many Kindles... and this is by far the worst experience.  I am currently in the process of returning this Kindle paperwhite signature edition... and it is literally taking weeks to process. I am chalking it up to a bad batch so be prepared for the luck of the draw when you order yours.  Again, the older kindles (i.e. the ones are now with limited support) never had this problem. I got a new Kindle delivered this last Saturday (9/24).  The issues were chalked up to bad goof by Amazon and some customer support agents that were ah... not thinking through the big picture, etc.  This customer agent was way better equipped in so many ways... from what she could do to how she acted and stated things... I wish all my interactions were done through her... she was FANTASTIC.  This is what I had come to expect from Amazon... so for my case... this was resolved since my new Kindle is working fine. text: The Kindle is amazing.Book replacement:Convenient for the space it takes and can replace books depending on how you use them. You can get virtually any book really easily just by emailing the files!And books on the kindle store are almost always way cheaper than phisical versions.Goodreads:It integrates with GoodReads so I can share what I am reading, update how far I am in books, rate the books and even share my favorite lines on books.Software:The software is intuitive enough where it took me about 20 minutes of tinkering with settings and now I am an expert on it. It locks and unlocks the kindle when you open or close it. It's sad that if you use this you won't see the cover of the book while the kindle is blocked, but not a deal breaker. I'd rather keep my kindle protected.This kindle supports wireless charging. Altho on my opinion this is NOT needed and I regret having spent more money on the stand for wireless charging by Anker. Having the stand to charge it wireless feels unneccesary since I would only have to charge the device once or twice a month.I'm in love and I will never go back to phisical books unless absolutely neccesary.

title: The best Kindle E-reader you can buy right now
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I bought this for my wife as an early Christmas gift. I have owned a Kindle Paperwhite for a few years, a 7th Generation model to be exact, but she has always used a Kindle Fire 7 for reading ebooks. She has been having a harder time sleeping and I thought it would be a good idea to reduce the eye strain she gets when reading at night by replacing her Kindle Fire. So far, it's a hit. The new Dark Mode and Warm Light Mode are the stand outs for her, and have made it much easier on her eyes in the evenings. Comparing it to my own Paperwhite, the new, larger screen is a huge improvement, and the way it lays flush with the rest of the device it extremely nice. Hopefully we won't have to test how waterproof it is, but I'm less nervous about getting caught in the rain with it than I would be with my older model. The real standout here is the USB-C charging port, and the wireless charging. Both our phones use USB-C, my Nintendo Switch Oled uses it, my headphones use it. We also have a portable battery bank with a built in wireless charger. All of this makes it easier to travel with the Paperwhite Signature edition than any other model of Kindle. The battery life is indeed long, but needing to charge in a pinch is much easier than with my older Kindle. I don't always have a Micro-USB cable with me and it's easier to not have to worry about needing one. I'd highly recommend this model if you're shopping for a new Kindle. I looked at all other currently available (Oct 2022) Kindle Models and this one, at least for now, stands far above the rest.

text: I’m not a Kindle fanboy, so here is my honest opinion. If you already have a tablet, there is not much reason to buy a Kindle. - screen, text quality: ipad is 200% better. The fonts are much sharper and the screen estate matters. Reading on 7 inch screen is ridiculous. - performance/sluggishness: kindle used to be a lot slower, yes it’s much better now but ipad is at least 4 times faster. - interface/UI: Kindle app interface could be better, but at least it’s better than the actual Kindle. The actual Kindle UI is back to 1980. - immersion reading: this means the audible is sync’d with the pages. It only works on Kindle apps, not on actual Kindle. This is the deal breaker for me. If this worked, I would have kept the Kindle for all its shortcomings. - weight: this is the only pro of the actual Kindle. Much easier on the hand. Contradicting my first bullet point about the screen size, 7 inch is a perfect size to put down in your coat pocket. As a transportable reading device, Kindle paperwhite is a perfect. - eye health: people say the actual Kindle is easier on eye. Personally, I can see why but need to test a bit more on this. I use greenish background on my ipad, which is surprisingly easy on eyes.So, here is my personal opinion. I read so many amazing reviews on Kindle, so I felt the need to balance it out a bit. I preordered Kindle Scribe, so I hope it will be better.

I've been reading on this kindle for 2 weeks, and it had 49% battery life right out of the box. I have read an incredible amount of hours, at least 35-40 hours, and my battery finally hit the 10% warning.I wish I had an option to look at reading stats directly from my kindle. I went to the app on my phone to look over stats and reading achievements. In addition to days/weeks read, I would like to keep track of how many hours I'm reading a day, week, month kind of like on my audible account. I wouldn't mind also being able to review the books I've read straight from my kindle device. None of this really takes away from the review, but are things I think woild improve my kindle experience.

text: Am in my second week of using my new Paperwhite Kindle. This is my fourth, having been through the Keyboard, the Touch, the Voyage and now the Paperwhite. Positives are it is clearer, perhaps easier to read because it is a bit sharper, charges wirelessly and has finally upgraded to the newer type C mini usb charging plug (yeah!). I am not thrilled with the software as opposed to my Kindle Voyage. I am big on having collections so I can put all unread books into an 'UNREAD' collection and I am very big on lists of books. I do not like the 'Grid' concept nor do I want to see covers. The Paperwhite does have a collections function but when it is used you lose the ability to sort by Title or by author. In all past versions I have used when you had a collection it was still sorted by author. In the Paperwhite that capability is no longer available. I strongly urge Amazon to add that function to a upcoming software change. The wireless charging dock works well and charges through the leather cover I purchased. The Paperwhite comes with a port that takes the mini usb C type charging plug/receptacle. Same as my Samsung S20FE phone so it is one less cord to travel with. Battery life appears good. Have been using about 1 hour per day for last 10 days and still has over 60% capacity.Along with the Paperwhite I purchased the wireless charging dock and because quite a few reviewers said the Amazon cover was poor quality I purchased the CoBak cover with stand and holding strap. High quality and real leather. Also has an inside spot to hold 1 or 2 credit card size items. Appears to work well as I dropped the Paperwhite and watched it bounce down my stairs. The Paperwhite came through fine but suggest you not try this on yours. I am not upset with the on button. Seems to work based on time. Have not measured but think after 6 or more hours the Paperwhite turns itself off and you must use the button to turn back on. Pressing left or right margins of pages causes the Paperwhite to go to the next or previous page. Fonts are selectable. Font size is selectable. Warmth and light intensity are also selectable.Software issues aside this was a good purchase. Every Kindle seems to have new 'quirks' and I am sure I will get over the loss of by author sorting when I am in Collections mode. That is the main reason I am rating 4 rather than 5.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: Nice Hardware, Software May Be Problematic
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I am a long-time Kindle user. I have loved every single Kindle I have purchased. My new Kindle may be the only one I don’t love which is disappointing – and it’s not the hardware that’s disappointing. I love the 17 LEDs, the additional warm lighting, and the slightly larger screen size. For the most part I find the default options are fine.About me: I have a very large library (5000+ books) and I always read off-line. And I prefer to have all my books (or at least as many as will fit!) downloaded on my device. I have organized my books into 36 collections (makes it easier to find a specific book…at least for me).I have been using a Kindle since the original keyboard so have been through several software upgrades. This is usually a seamless process. Unfortunately, I’ve had nothing but problems with this one.To begin with – I loved how it was already linked to my Amazon account. All my books were already listed on the device and just needed to be downloaded. I was happy – while time-consuming this isn’t difficult.First, I installed the software update that was waiting to be installed. Then I set about downloading my books onto the device. This is when I noticed that a number of books had been downloaded two or three times. I could not delete these phantom books.I did some research and discovered that some people had experienced the same problem with the 2018 Kindle and had resolved the issue by doing a factory reset. So, I did a factory reset. This significantly reduced the number of phantom books in my library. I still wasn’t entirely happy but could live with it.Two days later, after having spent hours downloading books, I was ready to start reading. While scrolling through my collections my Kindle froze and gave me an unexpected error message and the option(s) to deregister my Kindle, do a factory reset, or contact the support team. I opted for another factory reset.The second factory reset eliminated some more of the phantom books, but I also noticed that books I had purchased and downloaded were disappearing from the list of books on my device very shortly after I downloaded them. Some of the disappeared books simply moved to the end of the list of books by that author and some disappeared entirely. A few other books don’t seem to download at all.Based on the reviews, my problem seems to be an aberration. Right now, I’m frustrated. If I hadn’t traded in my Kindle when I purchased this one, I’d simply return the Signature edition and call it quits.I still strongly recommend a Kindle but perhaps not the Signature edition**********************************************************************************************************************Updated October 25, 2022I finally got all of my books loaded onto this Kindle. The number of duplicate entries (not duplicate purchases) did get drastically reduced after I did the second factory reset. A week later I actually got to begin reading a book on the Kindle.A really interesting book. I charged the Kindle last night and it was at 100%. Unplugged it from the charger and put it on my coffee table preparatory to finishing the book. Picked it up an hour later and it was showing an 88% charge. I thought that was odd but maybe my non-Amazon case wasn't properly shut.  Finished reading the book (noticed when I closed the cover a few times that the book cover was not displaying when I opened the case which I thought was odd but wasn't too concerned about).Wanted to return the book to the library. That's when the Kindle told me that it couldn't find the book in my library. There were no books in my library according to the screen I was on. So decided to change my view to listing the books and according to the statistics it showed 4000+ books were loaded on the Kindle. But I still couldn't find any books on the Kindle nor could I open any of my collections.So I restarted the Kindle. Once that process was completed all of my books had reappeared and the battery showed a 94% charge.I've done more factory resets on this version of the Kindle than I have ever done on any of my previous Kindles (I normally only need to do this when I get rid of an older Kindle). And I've done more restarts on this Kindle than on any of my previous Kindles (usually only did then when there was a software upgrade).I don't know what's going on but I am definitely not impressed and wish I hadn't decided to upgrade to the new Kindle.

text: I have used the kindle voyage for many years, and resisted “upgrading” to any of the newer kindles because I loved the page turn buttons and the origami case. The new features in this Kindle, namely wireless charging and waterproofing, convinced me to part with my beloved Voyage. And most of the time, I’m really happy I did. The new kindle has a bigger screen, it’s much faster, and while it’s annoying to move your thumb to change pages (you could change pages on the voyage without any hand movement) it’s not horrible.What _is_ horrible is the power button on the bottom. Who the heck though this was a good design decision? If I’m not accidentally pushing it with one of my knuckles holding the book, I’m pushing it with my belt buckle because I had the gall to place the device on my lap while lying down. I’ve lost count of the number of times I’ve had to wait for the book to reboot because of the stupid power button on the bottom.Come on Amazon, I know putting the button close to where the logic board is situated is cheaper, but this isn’t a cheap device. I suspect you can absorb the few cents it costs to relocate the power button to the side or top. I’d go for the top, personally, very little chance of hitting it accidentally there.Other than the power button, a very solid entry in the Kindle line. I wish they’d release an update of the Voyage that can be used without moving your hand, but barring that, I’ll definitely keep this one.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: (Almost) The Best Kindle Ever
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: My Kindle Voyage did not survive being laundered. Yes, it was caught up in the bedsheets. Too bad; that was IMO the best of all the Kindles in its time. But never mind, the Voyage is history.The new Paperwhite finally makes up for the shortcomings of its predecessors, by incorporating most of the best features of the best versions of each. It lacks only physical page-turn buttons, which is something I, at least can easily live without.From the Oasis it has the larger screen, the color-temperature adjustment, the auto-brightness. It did not, thankfully, retain the terrible battery life, the reason I traded my Oasis in.From the Voyage it has the absolutely perfectly even screen lighting.The regular version has the reasonable price of previous Paperwhites, and USB-C; the Signature adds the lack of ads and the extra storage for audiobooks.All it lacks is the feather lightness of the Voyage; the new Kindle is a handful. But add a hand-strap, or a case with a strap, and you'll never care about the weight.The battery life is prodigious. Have I mentioned that already? I've owned Keyboards, Basics, Paperwhites, Oases, Voyages, and this new Paperwhite beats them all. It seems like the battery level barely creeps downward.The software is pretty much the same across all my recent Kindles, and it's fine. Different people quibble about different features, and that's OK, but with some study you can usually figure out how to make it do what you want. It's more than fine, and compared to earlier Kindles it's sort of a miracle.The lack of cellular connectivity is a non-issue, IMO. Yes, if you don't have a phone that can provide a wifi hotspot, or you live in a wifi desert, or you don't have a computer, then maybe it's a problem. Or maybe your lack of connectivity in general is more of a problem. But cellular has always been the least-used method of getting books onto Kindles, so I can't criticize Amazon for no longer providing it for free.Meanwhile, my new Paperwhite Signature is scratching all my itches. My wife, who complains about everything, loves hers too.

options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I typically read 100-200 pages on a kindle paper white (2018) daily. I purchased this kindle with the phenomenal pricing on Black Friday. As the title reads, this is a massive tech upgrade from kindles as old as 4 years past. To my disappointment, the reading experience is the same to slightly less enjoyable.The very first thing I noticed from the moment my delivery woman handed me the package was that “this is heavy!” I knew I had to account for packaging and the box the kindle ships in (not the cardboard box, the protective device sleeve) but was still surprised as this was my knee-jerk reaction.The kindle came in mint condition and looked… well just like a kindle. Unboxing and holding the device independent of its packaging yielded the same reaction: it felt noticeably heavier than my old paperwhite.Powering up, the kindle arrived with 52% battery; which is no concern because it would certainly last all day. Setup up was LIGHTYEARS faster than my old paperweight. No lag when typing, web pages load mimicking a cellphone, settings change immediately, books open as fast as their physical counterparts.I immediately went after exploring the new features: warm lighting and dark mode- both which were encouraging factors for me to buy the upgraded paperwhite as apposed to the normal kindle-kindle.Both seems cool, but I can hardly imagine being in a position where I say “I need to use these features!” The actual reading experience isn’t largely impacted by use of either. I can imagine dark mode would be helpful if you’re reading in a pitched black room, but the warm lighting really didn’t seem to make a large impact. Books still put me to sleep if I’m tired with warm lighting or not.Now I consider myself more of a reader than someone who is obsessed with new features, and I’m disappointed to report that the new paperwhite is not any easier to read on, and may well be more difficult. Pages look great, display is crisp, but I cannot read with just one hand. For your own anyaltics, I’m a young man who wears a medium in medical gloves- the only way I could enjoy this e-reader with one hand was if I rested the weight of the kindle on my chest or a stand. I could not comfortably read on my back holding the device with one hand.In conclusion I think I will downgrade to the new and lighter/smaller kindle e-reader.  The new features on this kindle are cool, but not necessary of a upgrade just for their sake. If you read with two hands or prefer a large screen, you’ll probably love this device. In my case this e-reader does not create a comfortable enough reading experience and I will be seeking a more compact version.

(eg. For the time period, the Kindle DXG was a device engineered right.)PROS1) Good lightweight reading device, however after extened reading, does become slightly uncomfortable to hold.2) Very nice lighting choices.  Lighting is really the only significant reason for upgrading from the Kindle DXG version.CONS1) Not compatible with USB ethernet devices, or apparently does not include/activate Linux USB ethernet device driver!  The device is only able to use or includes the Linux wireless driver!  So trying to use a USB-C ethernet device while residing at your home, forget it, must use wireless/wifi.2) Wish books could contain additional ebedded dictionary information, for Ebooks containing words not found within the common dictionary.  Such as common Japanese words.  Currently, readers must actively be connected to the Internet for accessing additional word look-up (dictionary) methods such as using Wikipedia.  Only workaround, highlight the words requiring Internet access for later retrieval or have the additional dictionaries installed for manual look-up.3) Collections, a long time lack luster feature and the only sorting method for readers having lot of a books.  Books should be allowed to be sorted by users' file system folders/directories.  (eg. Build/engineer correctly first, then build/engineer upon what works allowing for fallback methods.)4) Power button is on the bottom end.  Heard others complain as well, however likely required for moisture prevention/rating.  Just need to be a little careful, and sometimes accidentally pushed.

text: I love, love, love this Kindle! I’ve used the Kindle app on my iPhone and iPad for many years; it is hands down the absolute best reading app. I spend an average of 8 hours a day reading on my iPad, and my daughter has been after me for at least 4 years to buy a Kindle because it is better for the eyes. I was very resistant because the Kindle just seems to dark for me. My eyes do not gather as much light as most people’s do, so I always have my brightness levels set higher than most people and a lot of lights on around me. I’m visiting my daughter this month, and she became quite insistent that I try her Kindle for better eye health. I spent a day fiddling with her font settings—type, size, boldness— as well as the brightness. By the end of the day, I had found the settings that gave me a clear reading experience and realized that I liked the size/weight difference compared to my iPad, so I shopped for a Kindle. I decided on the 6.8” Signature model because I felt that the size difference was important for my old eyes and that I might want the higher storage capacity to buy audible books in the future. Even though my daughter’s 10th was nice, the clarity of the characters is significantly better on this edition. I am glad that I bought the slightly larger version as I’m able to use a smaller font, thus having to turn the pages less often. I like being able to tap the side of the page vs swiping to turn pages. Daughter said that hers worked the same way, but I couldn’t get it to work and hadn’t gotten used to the slight flicker at the top, left corner of the page as it turns. This one is more seamless. Also there are more levels of brightness on this edition than on her 10th generation, and that has increased my reading experience. Another big win for the Kindle over the iPad is the battery life. I am very happy with my purchase and recommend this Kindle.

title: Got the device right - Need to fix User Interface (UI)
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: First let me say I am an early adopter of Kindle with over 3,000 books in my Amazon library and have had pretty much every device they have produced since the beginning.  This device they got right.  The larger screen is really great and the battery life is as promised.  I downloaded 6 books and read 5 plus a bit of the 6th before having to recharge which is really great.Now to the user interface which is problematic.  The "upgraded" user interface is pretty much unusable with a large library since the introduction of the thumbnail picture of book covers and the removal of the search for page & author.  The slide bar is just not useable when there are a large number of books in the library.  I would have to slide the dang thing 600 times to scroll through my library which is not doable.Also, many of us have spent years building collections which are useless under the current interface.  Collections can't really be brought to the forefront and used to classify books without going through all the slider stuff which isn't helpful either.And now to the worst part.  Everyone gets older and with that challenge comes changes in vision.  The menu's and library pages can't be enlarged and essentially I have to use a magnifying glass to be able to read them.  You would think there would be a solution to that as the font on books can be changed, but after multiple discussions with Kindle support the answer is NO.  I tried an Oasis but it is an unwieldly mess and the battery life was HORRIBLE despite the advertised additional life.  Returned it as unusable.  I do not like reading on an IPad or other tablet due to the weight, and the shiny screen which in the sunlight reflects horribly and is the whole point of the Kindle, to look like paper.I'm pretty much stuck due to my extensive library which would be difficult to recreate on another platform so Amazon, please fix the user interface problem.  A true reader doesn't care about the cover design, but the words in the actual book.

title: Very mixed bag. trending worse with updated review
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on December 24, 2021
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: The badThe battery though slightly better than my 2 gen old paperwhite still only last for about a day and a half.  Amazon's method of estimating battery life is a bit of a cheat. Basing it on a half hour of reading a day is ridiculous.  Some if us actually read books rather than pretending we can read. Its irritating but nothing new with Amazon.The new kindle is much less stable than the old one. My old one might lock up and crash every other week and the restart. Say every 50 or 60 hrs of reading. The new one which has updated since I got it a couple weeks ago crashes every day at least once. So....very serious down check there.3rd negative.. the older paperwhite had a bezel that the screen was inset into. Less risk of damage with that design as well as the more important point that it gave you a decent grip on it when holding it with one hand. Between larger size and lack of any texture such as that bezel this is a decent negative.ProsLove the lighter weight. It is notably lighter than my older paperwhite.Love the larger screen. Even with the slightly more awkwardness due to size.Love the 32 gigs storage. I was constantly fighting a lack on the old one (have the signature ed)Love love the usb c. I hated the old micro usb charging as it was failing due to wear of using it every day to charge. Also love that this unit charges in a couple hours compared to 8 or 9 hrs with old one.Wireless charging is nice but not a make or break thing for me. The way my bedside charging is set up it has ended up easier to just grab one of the usbc cables and plug it in rather than try and get it on the wireless charger and verify it is actually charging.Also like that it is supposed to be waterproof.If the crashing gets resolved i will  change to a 4 out 5 review.update jan 2023.. bought oct 2021 received just before christmas that year so I have been using it constantly for 13 months.Reduced rating to 2 starsThe locking up and rebooting have never gotten better through updates over the last year.In the last month or two all my books will disapear and have to be downloaded again. This has happened a couple times and amazon will ask me to re-download and when that works they go ok all fixed, and I go no its not fixed I had over a 1000 books disapear that were in my I want to read someday list on there and I have no clue what they are now because they are gone. Oh after last time it happened I side loaded about 400 books back on to it and it only saw about 100 of them.. Looked like the indexing job that scans them to show in the interface quit before it started and you can't get it to try again.  Whats the use of having a digital e-reader that I can't read all my books on. I spent extra for the 32 gig version because I always keep a lot of books on it. Suspiciously the books that dont show up are sideloaded books. Same ones that did show up till this issue started happening. I'm left wondering if amazon is pushing without saying so to only read books for the amazon store on their devices. Really really irked.In general this has been the slowest kindle I have ever owned and I have had them  since the first generation and I always buy the nicer version of which ever one I get. More storage or 3g connectivity when that was still a thing etc.. This one is the signature edition which was a bit more expensive. My speculation is that they saved a few dimes and put a cheaper processor in it. I'm constantly dealing with page lag when going to the next page and hanging up for 5 to 10 seconds a lot before it locks up and needs to be rebooted. I have reset it, no change.At this point I'm going to get one of the new generation larger android color e-ink devices that you can draw on, use play store so you can put apps on it and use it as a general purpose tablet as well as a reader. 1/2 of my reading is stuff not through amazon so not being able to use the kindle is rough.one of amazon's e-ink devices is still one of the only choices in my mind to read books through amazon on but do yourself a favor and avoid the 2021 paperwhite.oh another thing over the years I have noticed is that if you are hooked to the internet they can log into your device anytime they want. Every time I do a support call they will log in and change settings or look at stuff without need you to give them access.. That makes me uneasy. It's not particular to this kindle paperwhite model though, any of their tablets or kindles, alexa devices etc have that capability to allow them to access it whenever they want.

After one month. So I decided to buy the much less expensive Kindle Signature. I love it! The screen is much faster in its response time, there’s no waiting for the thing to boot up, it takes you right to where you left off, the text is beautifully clear with no ghosting. I love the auto-adjust light. No Hoopla, but many of the titles I’ve borrowed lately have been available via Libby, and kindle editions of books are very inexpensive. It’s a little smaller than the Boox, but that doesn’t bother me, and actually fits my hands better.  I love that the lock screen shows me my current book cover. title: Fast enough for foreign language study
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on April 2, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: This is my fourth e-reader. I'm upgrading from a 6th gen Paperwhite. This feels 2-3x faster and makes all the difference for the main purpose I've been waiting for, for years: being able to read a foreign language text where you need to look up a large number of words.I haven't carefully followed the evolution of these features, but now when you buy a Russian e-book, and first try to open it, it automatically downloads an ABBYY Russian-English dictionary. Long pressing on a word pops up the dictionary entry, if found. Otherwise, it searches Russian Wikipedia, but you can swipe over to a Translation tab that does something akin to Google Translate (on a word or entire passage). It takes just 1-2 seconds, so much faster than a physical dictionary. This is phenomenal and I think completely changes the world of foreign language study for someone who likes to read.The Vocabulary Builder feature and flashcards are particularly useful in this context as well!Secondly, I love the wireless charging feature on this edition. I expect it to mean not wearing out the charging port.Third, I love the new photography they feature on the lock screen. Artistic collections of fountain pens, pencils, letters, newspapers, and so on. It's the perfect front cover for my Kindle (apart from the highly recommended leather case).Back to my foreign language study, it could still be improved. The Wikipedia so far doesn't do me much good, so I wish I could configure the Translation tab to come up first (if the dictionary doesn't work). The dictionary often doesn't, I suspect because it is indexed only by the non-inflected word forms (such as verb infinitives). So some code and indexing could increase the hit rate. Alternately, a fuzzier search of the dictionary that provides likely matches could be useful.The Vocabulary Builder could also be improved. It should keep separate lists by language. It would be nice if you could drill yourself intentionally with flashcards (with say 20 words until you master them) rather than looping through the entire set. I have 650 already after reading three Chekhov short stories! :)I haven't tried other languages yet. I hope it's the same experience in German, French, Spanish, and Greek, which I should eventually get around to trying.

text: I have always loved the idea of eReaders since they came on the scene. The idea was always felt like "a thousand books inside your pocket". It was, and is, a great feeling to have so many options to read with so little to carry. The new Kindle Paperwhite is a marvel in that it provides everything it's predecessor did, and of course more (otherwise why change?). The amber light is perfect for reading just before bed, the response time is leagues better, and the resolution has made me feel like a got a stronger pair of glasses (because the definition is much sharper).However my one gripe is a small yet big change. They made this model bigger. Understandably it likely had to do with allowing more page-room for reading, perhaps better mimicking the book experience. However perhaps what was unseen is that due to this slight change it is suddenly just barely too big to fit into pockets. Pants pockets, jacket pockets, and it has sized out of some smaller backpack pockets it used to fit within. This is a shame. The promise of that thousand books in your pocket is still partially there, you just have to carry it in your hand inconveniently somewhere. If I could make the choice again, I would sacrifice all the new features for my older model which is smaller. Unfortunately I traded it in. Yet this kindle is still wonderful, and if it is your first, you are bound to enjoy it.

text: I’ve been using an old Kindle Paperwhite I got about ten years or so ago since I received it as a birthday gift, and it’s served me well enough. I decided to buy the new generation’s signature edition as my old one is now running quite slowly and I wanted to purchase or download my college course materials onto it for easier transport and storage, and knew I couldn’t sit in class waiting for a page to load for two minutes. This purchase did NOT disappoint. I’m amazed at the speed this device operates, and there is little to no ghosting that I’ve noticed. I’ve read textbooks, comics, and fun books on it (including PDFs I’ve sent to it) and none of them have proven an issue for this excellent piece of equipment. Accessing Goodreads on it, or even the internet browser, was an added bonus I didn’t realize I’d appreciate so much! This is one of the best investments I’ve made towards my schooling and my reading. The compatibility with audiobooks was another surprise I didn’t see coming. The only thing I’ve noticed is that the battery life doesn’t seem as long as my old Kindle. It seemed like I could plug the old one in overnight and it would last an entire month of fairly consistent use! This one I find myself docking far more often, and as unfortunate as that is, it only makes me appreciate the wireless charging dock more. Otherwise, zero complaints from me, though I’d say that last one doesn’t count as a complaint, considering this device still lasts longer than my phone and laptop battery! If you’re looking for your next E-Reader, look no further than this, you won’t regret it.

title: Just a few flaws with this excellent reader
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: The Paperwhite Signature Edition screen's adjustable and automatic brightness, the selectable fonts and their sizes, and the adjustable screen tint are all positives and very welcome. The size is satisfactory and the weight is OK.I have all but given up buying actual books over the years and have substituted Kindle issues instead. I've owned 5 Kindles, starting with the "keyboard" (which still works fine) and it's been interesting watching the technical advancement over the years. I've accepted the Kindle as my primary reader for novels of which I read nearly 100 per year.Perhaps it is poor luck, or perhaps a decrease in reliability, but I've returned two Signature Editions and am hopeful this third one is not flawed. The first one, after a month, had intermittent battery problems and the second one locked up on the graphic of the kid under the tree and wouldn't change. Fortunately, Amazon is extremely good at replacing faulty items of which I am very thankful.The other little inconveniences I've noticed with the Signature is the sensitivity of the screen when page turning seems variable. Many times, it seems to turn two pages instead of one and sometimes I need to touch several times to get it to turn a page at all. I would like to see that become either an adjustable setting or actually retro back to the paging buttons of the keyboard issue. The old keyboard issue also had audible reading function which would be nice to return. The menu and library functions have not advanced much and are awkward. I wish after you read a book, it would automatically put it in a separate "read" section so it wouldn't interfere with browsing your unread books.But most of all, I cannot understand why they have not moved the power button to the top of the reader instead of placing it right under your finger of your right hand where it accidentally gets turned off as you're reading. Even the keyboard issue, which had it's power button in the same place, was better, because it was slide-operated instead of push operated.Nevertheless, I highly recommend digital books and the Kindle readers for your reading enjoyment.

title: The Best Kindle Paperwhite Yet
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: Purchased my first Kindle Paperwhite in 2016 and the 10th Gen in 2019 because I desparately needed the 8G storage. Didn't trade in because I wanted a spare Kindle, just in case. Saw the latest Signature version and finally traded in my Gen 6, choosing the bundled offer as I needed a cover and wanted to take advantage of the wireless charging feature.Love the Signature Paperwhite and the 32G of storage. ​Didn't think there would be much difference between my 10th Gen 8G (with ads) but this is truly an upgrade. Books download almost instantly, and with plenty of storage onboard don't think I'll ever run out of room. I can choose my lighting shade and brightness, and fonts and such are easier to manage. I can see even better than before inside or out, day or night. The on/off button is positioned better for me, I'm left-handed, and haven't accidentally turned off my Kindle once during the approx 10 books I've read since purchase. Didn't really think the ads used to bother me. However, now when I open my Kindle without ads it takes me directly to the last page read, more like a traditional book. No distractions invading my precious reading time. The 11th Gen is slightly bigger, nicely balanced in my hand. Arthritis is creeping in, yet I can hold the book for extended periods and easily manage the touchscreen. Notes are becoming evermore intuitive, therefore easier to use. My new Kindle seems to stay cleaner and look nicer, overall. No noticeable fingerprints or crumbs stuck around the edges anymore. Okay, I admit that I read during dinner almost every night, but I do use fragrance free, gentle, disposable face cloths or microfiber cloths to wipe it clean. Wireless charging is easy, just follow the instructions. Have only charged it once since it really does have a longer battery life than previous generations. Miss my 10th Gen premium leather cover a lot, the 11th Gen leather cover doesn't feel like leather. Has the plastic feeling of reconstituted leather. Found an Oberon Design leather cover that I'm going to invest in. Reading is my passion, and the cover is part of the experience. Thought I'd never give up hard cover and paper back books. But in 2018 I started donating my collection, and now have one small bookshelf left, filled with books I've yet to read or special keepsakes. I have a lot more space, and a lot less to dust.

options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: My first foray into the Kindle reader has been wonderful. I originally bought it to study for technical exams, but have since enjoyed reading recreationally. While I have tons of tech, and access to Audible and the Kindle reader on my iPhone and iPad, they are also too distracting, often eye-straining, heavy, and constantly in need of charging.The Kindle Paper White is a reading device that’s easy to use and maintain, lightweight and unobtrusive, easy on the eyes in any lighting easy find reading material. Not only can you get books or audio books from Amazon Kindle or Audible, but you can usually get them from your local public library for free. I use the Libby app on my iPad, connected to my local library system to find books in Kindle format, and can then access them on the Kindle.Battery life, for my moderate daily use is insane… about 3+ weeks between charging, and I can charge via cord or wireless on the same wireless charging pad that my iPhone uses.For the case I opted for much more affordable and more versatile Fintie Stand Case for $20 US, about half the cost of the Kindle Leather cover.In summary, it’s a purpose designed and built reader that does a great job as a reader, and without all of the distractions of other devices.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: Software constantly crashed and froze
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I have had several Kindle Paperwhite’s in the past. I was so excited to see this newest version with the 32 GB since they’ve discontinued the option for 32 GB on the regular Kindle Paperwhite. From day one it was unfortunately a complete POS. I can’t tell you how many times it froze in the first week alone, and I had to restart it with hard resets, which would take up to 30 minutes before I could get back into the book I was reading. Then recently, the dark mode became completely unresponsive, so I can’t get out of it and that is the only way I can read the books anymore. Then, when I finish reading a book I would tap the library tab, but that also became completely unresponsive, and I could never get back to the library unless I did another hard reset, which took another 20 to 30 minutes before it would respond and I could get back into the library.I had considered exchanging it for another one, but after reading many other negative reviews by people that have the same issues, it seems they didn’t have any more luck with the new e-reader sent to them. I didn’t want to risk it since I’m so close to my return window expiring. It will be interesting to see how the return goes since I was going to trade in my old Kindle Paperwhite 10th generation 32 GB for this one. Luckily I hadn’t sent it in yet because the minute I started having these issues I decided to wait. I would purchase the brand new Kindle Paperwhite that came out this week if they hadn’t gotten rid of the 32 GB option and only offer up to 16 GB now. I know to most people that seems plenty but not for everything I like loaded on my e-reader.I was also excited to see the new Signature Edition offered a warm setting since I used to have a Barnes & Noble Nook and they had a great warm setting on theirs. I didn’t really care for the one on this one as much though, and just kept it in the dark mode to read in the evening. I just don’t understand why they can’t have the same software that they have on their Kindle Fires. I have one of those, but the battery goes down ridiculously fast, even if I have it in airplane mode when I’m reading, so it’s not even an option to read on that one.And don’t get me going on the software update they did several months ago, where someone in their infinite stupidity, decided to get rid of the back button. I used to be able to look up an author, scroll through the books, go into a book, and then if I wanted to check another book by the same author, I could just hit the back button and go down the authors list again. Once they got rid of the back button (it used to be located in the upper left-hand corner right next to the library back button ) now every time I want to do that, I have to go back to the library, put in another search, put in the authors name again and start over.Maybe you’ll be one of the lucky ones if you purchase this e-reader and have more luck than I did with it. I decided to purchase a new one because my Kindle Paperwhite 10th generation was 4 years old and had started to freeze occasionally, but nowhere near the the level this one did. I guess I’ll just have to keep that one until something better comes along somewhere down the road when they hopefully have solved their software issues. I’m still holding out hope that with some future upgrade on the software, they’ll bring the back button back as well.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: This is a painful upgrade, and it shouldn't be
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2021
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I've stuck with the same Kindle Paperwhite since just before Columbus sailed off to find India, and missed, so I had no idea what I was in for when I decided it was time to get the latest and greatest. It arrived tonight, just about an hour ago.Unboxing? Piece of cake. Nice look, nice feel. Slid right into the leather cover I also bought for it. Booted right up, and we went into setup. A bit of a stumble when it came time to enter my password, but hey, my fault for using a complex password. Then it started on the endless (as far as I know, it is endless) series of "Do you want to buy this/subscribe to this/get this?" No to everything isn't an option, so one at a time, until I got to that Amazon Kindle subscription service they always push. Choosing no wasn't an option. Sure, it said I could choose no, but pressing the "No thanks" button got me exactly nowhere. After a couple minutes of having it ignore No thanks and insist I choose something else, I forced a reboot, because I am NOT going to get something I don't want, just because they really want me to. When it came back up, we'd moved past all the questions, and I was looking at my library. It had gotten there suspiciously fast. So I tried to open a book. No dice. The books were listed - I could see the cover art - but I had to download each book separately, by going in and trying to open it.What about the poor people who don't check and find out until they're out of wifi range? Gee, too bad for them, I guess. No warning of this, of course.I've been going through page after page of books, downloading each one, and it's painfully slow. It isn't my connection, that's fast. I can stream 4K to 3 televisions at the same time, and still browse the internet, without any problems, so the slowness is on the Amazon side. Oh, and there's an exciting new feature! It shows the cover art, until I download the book. Then the cover art disappears, and it's just the generic Kindle rectangle, with the book title. And the book series aren't numbered, like they were on my old Kindle. And as I've downloaded more books (on my Signature series, that boasts being able to hold thousands of books) the screen response time has gotten slower, and slower, and slower. Right now it's about 2-3 seconds between touching the screen, and having the Kindle do anything.My hope is, the new Kindle is just indexing everything, and that's what is bogging it down so much. Sure, they could have coded it to wait until after there was no activity for a few minutes to start indexing, but I live in hope.Oh, and the book sorting is, of course, totally hosed. The book series I was in the middle of reading before the upgrade is buried somewhere down around page 47 in the library. And it didn't restore my placemark, so I'll have to hunt around and see if I can find where I left off. But I won't have to worry about that until I've gone through and downloaded all the books, one at a time. I'm on Page 24 of 48. And I've only been doing this for an hour.Hey, Kindle programmers! I have an idea! After the setup, give me a button that says "Download complete library". And whatever it's doing besides downloading books, hold off on that until they're all downloaded. I could be watching TV, or entertaining my parrot, or playing with my dogs, but instead I'm babysitting an electronic appliance. In case it's been too subtle, I resent the time I'm wasting doing it.

title: Went a bit beyond my expectations
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on December 1, 2021
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I've had this for over a month now and have finally used it enough to provide some feedback.  First, the main thing that took getting used to was the size...it's bigger and at first it felt too big.  But after a couple of weeks, it feels just right and I appreciate the extra space on the screen.  It's still relatively light and easy to hold.As for the screen, the lighting does seem more uniform, and I really appreciate the warm lighting, especially when reading in bed.  It does not seem to affect my spouse's sleep whenever I end up reading in bed and she is asleep.  And I think I end up going to sleep sooner after reading with this lighting...I'm guessing less blue spectrum is helping with that.USB-C, ah would have been a deal breaker for me and I would have jumped ship had it not been on this Kindle.  It's great to have it and it should have been on the last version.  The wireless charging works fine and gives me another option for charging it.  As for the power button on the bottom, it's a non-issue, and I haven't accidentally turned it on or off even once.I'm not a great fan of the newer UI, but if you tweak it a bit, you can make it more classic, so I'm fine with that.  It is maybe a bit faster than my last paperwhite when turning pages, but is always responsive.  There have been very, very few times that I've had to touch the side twice to get it to turn.  It's certainly more responsive than my 2017 model Paperwhite.  It does take a bit longer to actually wake when it's been off for a longer time.  But wake-up is pretty snappy if you haven't had it off for many hours (just timed it...about 1 sec).Battery life seems better than my 2017 model.  I replaced the battery in that older version and the comparison is a noticeable improvement even over that new battery.  I think I've charged it twice over the past 5 or 6 weeks.  I read just less than 1 book per week for comparison so your battery mileage may vary depending on how much you use wifi, and how bright you like your screen.Overall, I'm very glad I purchased this and it did exceed my expectations.

text: This kindle was an upgrade from a much older Paperwhite I had for years. title: it changed my life!

text: This is the first dedicated e-reader i have ever owned. Previously, i used either my phone, ipad or a samsung tablet for reading. What i did not understand is that phones and tablets operate with backlit LED technology, where the kindle e-readers use the e-ink technology.So why is this important... well, i can now read outside in the sunlight and still be able to read my book without the glare and low contrast that is inherent with LED based screens. I can read with my sunglasses on, even. I can also read late at night and when i am finished reading, i am able to fall asleep quickly (the back lighting from LEDs stimulates the brain and messes with your circadian rhythms). I am now able to stop reading... on the LED devices, there is a compulsiveness associated with those screens... its similar to the way that the casino video terminals / VLTs work... the lights and motion stimulates dopamine. As someone with ADHD, this can be a challenge. Now i have better control over my reading, I am able to savor my book choices, i am sleeping better and more consistently, and i am able to read whereever i want.This is the best thing ive purchased in years!!

text: Second Edit:  OK, I love this thing.  The battery life is GREAT.  I've been reading quite a bit (hours a day) and also turning it on and off a lot while loading books and messing around with settings.  I'm leaving WIFI on all the time. After 4 days, power is still at 88%.  My Oasis would have definitely been close to needing charging by now, even with WIFI off.  I've also engaged the automatic light setting that warms the color (I have it set at about the middle warmth setting from 8 pm to 8am for my evening reading and morning paper).  Very nice.  I used to use the 'dark' setting in the evening.  That was fine, but it was kind of a strange reading experience.  The warm color is very comfortable and pleasant, and still lowers the ambient light so that my wife is not bothered by it if I read late in bed.  Finally, this unit downloads very quickly compared to the Oasis and my other previous Kindles.  I checked the specs and it is capable of using the 5G WIFI channel.  Nice!I am an avid reader and have owned every Kindle model except the latest OASIS, which was a very minor update to the second version from 2017.  I currently use the second OASIS model and am a fan.  However, the glass/metal design is a bit heavy when combined with its size and it was always a bit slippery to hold.  When I saw this Paperwhite Signature update with a screen that is virtually the same size as the OASIS (looks the same when placed side by side, but it is listed as slightly smaller) in a smaller, somewhat lighter package along with wireless charging, I was sold.  The low price is a bonus.I noticed the increase in speed immediately.  The screen quality is great and I will enjoy the different color shades carried over from the newest OASIS.  It wirelessly charges seamlessly.  GREAT.  The extra storage capacity is not a big deal for me, since I only store books, but I'll take it.I haven't had it long enough to comment on battery life, but anything is better than the OASIS, which sucks battery power, and I would guess this will be an improvement.All in all a nice update, and except for the page turn buttons, gives you pretty much everything the  current OASIS has to offer in a smaller, lighter package with some nice updates.  Very happy!Edit:  I downloaded the software update, which is now on the kindle update page. Very nice. I assume it will auto update for most users soon

title: A big let down.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on November 24, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I just got my 11th generation kindle signature version. I normally use my iPad or iPhone to read Kindle. I have been considering getting a Kindle for years and I finally gave in and got one for the sake of eye strain because I read for several hours at a time.Pros:-light weight-long battery-less eye strainCons:It regularly turns the page more than once if I tap/swipe the screen one time. It also goes the wrong direction when I want to go back to a page because it went forward too many times. I know there’s a delay because of the device technology and the fact that it is a digital ink, However it does not respond well to touch in multiple ways. Swiping only works well if you press firmly and swipe. Half the time the lights swipes I make do not work well or they turn in the wrong direction. The most infuriating part is the fact that the power/screen saver button is on the bottom next to the charging port. I cannot begin to state how bad of a design flaw this is. No one I know holds a book from the top or a device from the top. Holding both sides of the device for long periods of time is not comfortable let alone normal body mechanics. And it is ridiculous to think anyone will hold it with two hands either.  You cannot hold the device one-handed like you would any book or phone or tablet and not have it continually and accidentally activate the screen saver button. You can’t even use most stands that have a space for the charging port or not at the bottom and not accidentally turn the kindle off. I’m upset that I even paid extra to get the one without advertisements and the whole device works so poorly and is so poorly designed after the 11th generation! I am heavily considering returning the product though I am not the type of person that likes to return something unless it’s broken or is not what is advertised. This will likely be the last time I ever purchased a Kindle product if they can’t get the most basics of design and function down after 11 generations. Worst part is I bought another Kindle paperwhite for my brother at the same time and he is not a big reader. He is also not patient with things that have issues. If his book that he reads continually switches to screen saver mode/turns off while he’s reading, it will only take a few times and he will never pick it up again. I have wasted a lot of money both for myself and  as a gift. Lesson learned.After watching the video again of the product, I noticed how everyone was holding it in the advertisement. Not something I would’ve thought to look for, or at, before I purchased it. But none of them hold it like you would normally with a finger underneath. The way they hold it, it will always slide out of your hand with or without a case. Unless they have Spiderman grip it will not stay in your hand like that easily, or for long.  You have to put one finger or so on the bottom to hold it from sliding down like you would any device you’re holding in your hand. Even if you wedge it into your palm, the moment you shift, change hands or otherwise, it still has the same problem with slipping.  So even in the advertisement,they are being subtly deceptive.

location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on December 9, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: It has been several months since I bought this edition of Kindle.  Unfortunately, I cracked my previous Kindle when I dropped it on its face.  The last edition, I was able to download anywhere without WiFi.  This addition you need to be connected to wifi.  One of my biggest complaints is the home screen view.  Absolutely hate the listing of book recommendations that take up most of the front page.  I thought I was buying a Kindle free of advertisement, but I guess they feel the book recommendations aren't advertisement.  I beg to differ on that point.  I hate that the home page shows the cover of the book.  I like my books in list form without the cover.  When in public if I have a risky front page, I don't want everyone seeing what I'm reading.  It's also annoying to have to scroll to find a book since most of the home screen are book recommendations. When trying to remove a book from the home screen most of the time I can't get it removed from my view.I don't know what the issue with this edition is but I've had to restart my Kindle much more for being frozen and or missing the home screen function.  This is the first Kindle that I've owned that I am disappointed in the functionality.  I really want my old Kindle back.  Less freezing and no advertisements.  So much for new and improved.  Good for authors who pay for their recommendations to appear in certain genres.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: Not Compatible with Some Technical Books but very Portable
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on April 10, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: The Kindle PaperWhite Signature is very portable.  I can fit the kindle with the kindle cover in the front pocket of my Docker's pants, and I am a smaller than average size man.  The brightness and contrast of the screen are easy to read during the day and at night.I had a hard time getting used to Paperwhite Signature's squarish screen.  The screen's width is almost equal its height.  For a fast reader, this is non-optimal.  I felt like the lines were too wide and I was constantly turning pages.  It also made it harder to read long sections of programming code.The biggest disappointment was finding out the Paperwhite Signature cannot read a kindle book format that many technical books and textbooks are published in.  This is not ePub to mobi file format issue.  The Signature Paperwhite cannot read the following technical books I bought from Amazon's Kindle store:"Introduction to Algorithms" 3rd Edition MIT Press"Understanding Cryptography: A textbook for Students and Practitioners""Digital Communications: Fundamentals & Applications" 2/eThese book are readable on the Kindle apps and my Kindle Fire 7, but the Signature Paperwhite says it is incompatible type.  (shown in the attached picture)I tried for two weeks to get used to wider aspect ratio of the screen and more frequent page turns, but every time I read on a Kindle App or my Kindle Fire 7, I enjoy the experience more.  After I found out I could not read all of my technical books on the Paperwhite Signature I decided to return it.  I run a software development business and primarily read technical books and business books, so this kindle version does not fit my needs.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: Amazing and Powerful Portable Library
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on May 6, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I usually don't like to read and I really never did much reading in school. I decided to change that in 2022 by purchasing a Kindle Paperwhite.I am proud to say, I enjoy the reading experience on the E-Reader over physical books. For one, I can hold the kindle in one hand (usually I use 2, but I can use just one). This is a huge benefit because I have my other hand free if I need to. The Kindle is waterproof so I don't have to worry about the rain or wet hands if I go to the beach or travel. It is also the fraction of the weight of a book so I can bring it anywhere with ease!The only downsides to the Kindle were occasional glitches where the Kindle goes full white screen and I have to reset it. Another con is the fact that on occasion it will glitch and skip forward 2 pages on one press. What could also be a con is the fact is has a battery. The battery lasts a long time, I have not charged my device in over a month and it is still about 60%. It's all dependent on how much and how long you read. That being said, for most users it should last quite a long time.Overall, my experience with the Kindle has been nothing but phenomenal. The colors are great, the user experience is great, and it is worth the investment if you want to read just about anywhere.

text: I know you’re not supposed to love inanimate objects but… I LOVE MY KINDLE. I love reading and the fact that I can take my books with me everywhere I go now is just… I‘ve already read 4 books on it and I’ve only had it for a week. For the people who are jumping into the Kindle game assuming it’s a high tech piece of technology, you will be sorely disappointed. It’s not. It’s literally an electronic book that is supposed to serve one purpose and that is to read. The page turning is great, I prefer tapping/swiping vs. buttons to turn the page. It’s extremely anti-glare which is amazing, especially when reading on the beach. I haven’t had any issues with the power button being in my pinky space buuut I do see how it could get in the way. It’s really the only design flaw. If you’re an avid reader, please do yourself a favor and take the jump.Side Note: I have Amazon Prime and pay for Kindle Unlimited which I think are both worth the price. I was paying almost $100.00 or more a month buying books and now I will be paying a little under $200.00 a year to read as many books as I want.

title: Soft light is a great addition
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on February 17, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: This is my fourth Kindle. I started with a second generation, then a Paperwhite, next the Voyage, and now this 11th Edition Paperwhite. I wear them out which is why I purchased another. Overall, I like the reading experience on this Kindle, I especially love the soft light feature. With many different fonts to choose from, it is easy to find one that makes reading easy. This screen is larger, so there will be less page turning, or if a larger font is needed, there will be more room. I haven't used this long enough to gage the battery life, but I was charging my Voyage 3-4 times a week so even if I only need charge this once a week, that'd be great, and the wireless charging is a big plus. One thing I do not like is the page turning. On this model, you touch anywhere on the right side to advance and anywhere on the left side to go backward. On my Voyage, there was a small area on the bottom left to touch to go backwards and you could touch the screen anywhere else to advance. This is a great feature if you are holding the Kindle with your left hand and want to turn the page. I truly miss this feature. Another thing I do not like is the highlights from others are on, and I cannot find how to turn highlights off. I do not care what passages others have found interesting and I find having them on to be distracting. I looked through the users guide and found nothing to help me in this area. Overall, I am happy with this Kindle and would recommend it. The longer battery life will def be appreciated.

text: So, after 9 months of almost daily use.... The quality of the screen, the auto/adjustable front/warm light, the excellent battery power, the speed of the device, the really nice page turn animation, etc... all combine to make this the best Paperwhite period.  However, the one thing that keeps it from getting 5 stars for me is the power button placement.  At least 2-3 times a week I end up accidentally pressing the power button as it's on the bottom of the device and too close to where I hold the Paperwhite. It's easy enough to press the power button and get back into reading but it's a subtle frustration that mars an otherwise excellent experience.  For future releases, I'm hoping the power button is moved to the top of the device instead.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: A Worthy Upgrade
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2021
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: This, for just the built in amber light alone and extra storage was worth the upgrade from my beloved Voyage. The larger size was a bit awkward at first but I got used to it quickly once my cover arrived, and speaking of covers - they are really necessary; they protect the device and actually make one handed reading much easier. The size is much bigger than my Voyage & while that one would easily fit in my smaller purses, this new Paperwhite is noticeably bigger and I'm not sure it was really necessary.Some have complained about ut the bottom on/off button & while I haven't found that a problem yet, I did prefer the button on the Voyage to this. Battery life is solid and sooo sooo glad of the USB upgrade!The amber lighting option is a game changer - I'm a non stop reader and bed reading is how I relax. The amber light is a much kinder light for tired eyes and reducing blue light later in the day is a must.After my Voyage I found the altered user interface a bit awkward & burying things like turning off other's highlights (it's in the Font menu in the "More" section - WTH?) and page turn automation in the Font menu rather than in Reading Options was just plain stupid. I mean, really? I had to search through reviews of the non signature version to figure out how to access those options, which, since this is now my 6th Kindle, I shouldn't have had to do. And that is why this is a 4 star device not a 5 star. Maybe they'll fix this issue in future firmware/ software upgrades (please!).Overall, I preferred my Voyage in terms of size and overall usability BUT I am not sorry that I bought this new Signature Edition. The lighting upgrade was a must for me and I really disliked the Oasis in terms of shape and price.So, the short answer is that whether you go for the regular or this Signature edition, the new Paperwhite is a must if you're an eReader fan.

title: Trying to Return or Exchange to No Avail
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: Edit No. 2:I see this product has been reduced for the promotion period and frankly I would rather return it for an exchange on a Fire 8 HD Plus but I can't get an actual human being at customer service.  So, down to one star.  I rarely use it because the screen resolution is so bad.  I think that some of these rave reviews might not be genuine.  Beware.October edit:I have reduced my number of stars from 3 to 2 after using this product for a couple of months. The best thing I can say is that the battery is very good and reading in the sun with or without sunglasses is absolutely outstanding. However, the screen is totally glitchy. As others have mentioned you can touch to turn the page and it will jump ahead one or five or 10 pages and any amount of trying to figure out what you’re doing wrong is futile.In my original review I expressed concern about the brightness of the screen and the fuzziness of the printing. I find this more than annoying. I never use this product to read on unless I am in bed in the dead of night, or sitting outside in the sun. Those 2 situations represent barely 10% of the time that I read. I am back to reading on my iPhone or my iPad and I intend to buy a new Kindle Fire or possibly a refurbished small iPad to use just for reading. The Kindle app is excellent and frankly works better than the Paperwhite itself so I am not concerned about how it will perform on other devices. Please read all of the reviews and carefully weigh what you value about your electronic reading device. Screen clarity is extremely important and this product simply does not have that and the user interface is just nuts.When my beloved Kindle Fire started dying I decided to move over to the Paperwhite Signature Edition because of all the hype and good reviews. I read on my iPad Air and I just needed a tool for reading that was smaller and easier to carry around.Two things I absolutely hate-first, the screen is dull even with the “warmth” setting turned all the way down, it’s poorly back lit and that is with the light turned all the way up as bright as it will go. I would hate to see what it does on its own with the auto adjust feature. As others have said, I turned that off first thing. Dark mode is awful in my opinion. I also think the text is not as crisp and I experimented with fonts and bold settings.Second, getting a toolbar or dialog box up to make changes or bookmark a page or get to Home takes more than one step, is not intuitive (Swipe up? Swipe down? Tap corner? Pick pick pick). Give us a toolbar that is in one place with one tap. This has always been an issue with Kindle product but on this device it is particularly goofy.Also, when I am reading and turn the page it will often jump to dark mode on its own and then return to light mode.The monochromatic scheme would not be so annoying if the screen was brighter but looking at the black and white book covers on the Home Screen, you can barely read them. I understand part of the deal with this device is no color but that is a deal breaker.As others have said there is no way to just turn off Wi-Fi, you have to use airplane mode.  Annoying.Two good things, the battery life is outstanding if you turn off Wi-Fi. And it’s petite size is perfect for one-handed reading in bed and it fits in just about any handbag and most pockets so you can read it in places (waiting rooms, lines, public transportation) where you might read on your phone so eye strain might be reduced. The water resistance is not a feature I care about.I would return it but it was a gift from my husband. I did get a swell cover for it which I recommend…https://www.amazon.com/dp/B09LH4NXKC?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_details.If you love your Kindle Fire, love your iPhone and iPad you will not like this. Sadly, I do not recommend.
