title: Disappointed
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 9, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: With improvements this e-reader could be a five star.  I had gotten this e-reader not just because the e-ink and front light are suppose to protect our eyes.  I hope it does.  I had read on the Amazon web site that it could be used for both kindle books and audible books.  However, they failed to mention that it is only the audible books which you have purchased.  You can not access any audible plus books.  I do not understand why the e-reader can not be made where readers can use the e-reader for both their kindle unlimited accounts as well as their audible plus accounts.  E-readers should not be competing in a matter where readers can only read specific books.  When readers buy a paperback or hard print book in a store;  no matter who published, printed or wrote the book they are able to read them anywhere or anytime.  Also, who wants a radio without speakers?  It is the same with e-readers.  Readers want them made with speakers and wired headphones/earplug jacks.  (Some of us refuse to use bluetooth earplugs for fear of brain cancer.)  Also, the device should come with everything needed for it to be used such as charging cable and plug.  No one wants to pay for an unfinished product or half of one.  Customers can always buy a different cable, plug or charger if needed but these should be provided with purchase so product is usable.  Companies can compete by improving their devices so that they offer more and better features and services such as color e-ink and larger sizes of e-readers.  That being said the kindle paperwhite e-reader is a fairly nice e-reader with quite a few settings.  Although it does not rotate or flip pages automatically; it does have a page orientation setting and just use your finger to flip pages.  There are numerous settings for font type, size, theme, light adjustments and etc.  Although you can not currently download your library app;  “Libby” does offer letting you download and read your books on your kindle e-reader at checkout.  However, the kindle paperwhite has no color like the Libby app so everything will be in black and white.  Also, do not attempt to clean/disinfect the back black plastic of the e-reader with alcohol as it stripped the glossy shiny coating off mine. (Maybe I will try metal frame and backing next time.)

title: It's an Oasis with Amazing Battery Life, No Buttons, and Wireless Charging.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I've had the Paperwhite. The Oasis. and now this new Paperwhite Signature edition.The Paperwhite was amazing, and fully sold me on the technology. Its like glimpsing at the future. Battery life measured in weeks. Screens that only ever get easier to read. Images that actually look like drawn images rather than a jpg because of the screen. It hooked me. It broke, but ill never forget the experience.The Oasis took me out of the market completely. It had everything I wanted, except for the battery life. Having to charge it every day meant its battery would quickly begin to degrade (as all lithium batteries do), if I used it which I never did, because it charged slowly and drained quickly. Why ever pick it up? The page turn buttons are a good sell but not at the expense of weeks of battery. If this thing had the battery of a paperwhite, or a little worse, there would be nothing better. But it doesnt, so dont buy it.The Paperwhite Signature Edition is everything I loved about the paperwhite, with a screen like the Oasis (the extra however many lights make no difference), the performance of the oasis, and a wireless charging dock to give it a home in the house. It does not have page turn buttons, but those are an extreme luxury (for some reason, it cant be expensive to add in a factory) and don't make much of a difference to the experience.Honestly has returned me to the market for these.

text: This device is so good and I’m so glad I went with the SE. I love the screen. It’s awesome, but that’s not surprising because 300ppi is still great. But I still think the Basic’s screen is still good. Sorry, not sorry. With that said I wouldn’t want to switch back and forth between 167ppi and 300ppi. It’s gotta be one or the other. The size of the screen was what really appealed to me and that’s why I wanted to upgrade. But I wouldn’t have if this weren’t a gift. I’m very selective about where I spend my tech money. I love the contrast on the 11th Gen. I love the contrast of my Basic and that’s the standard for me. I personally didn’t like the contrast of the 10th Gen Paperwhite.Dark Mode and warm light are everything! I seem to be in the minority, but I love the auto-light sensor. I think it works very well. I have no complaints thus far.I’m so glad the Kindle logo isn’t white. I wish it were a shade or two darker, but overall I’m very happy. People may think I’m ridiculous, but I would’ve sent it back if the logo was white. I absolutely hate the white logo on the 10th Gen Paperwhite.The screen is a fingerprint magnet. I will miss my Basic Kindle’s screen. It just takes forever to see smudges on it. I feel like if you look at these flush screens wrong you’ll have nothing but smudges.🤣 Again, this isn’t a big deal because I knew it was going to be this way. I always have a cleaning cloth near me and I can’t see the smudges while reading anyway. It’s still annoying though.I love that the USB C port is centered on the device. I hate how it was off center on my Basic. My Basic always sat funny on the dock I use at my desk when I’m sideloading new books.

text: I have read so many reviews on this paperwhite kindle 11th generation of customers LOVING it so after having one of the original kindle since 2013, I decided to break down and purchase a new one...A big mistake and a waste of money..I certainly love the wireless charger, a plus and also am able to charge my cell phone on the stand as well..Both have charged quickly and without issues with the covers on...The charger I found to be functionable....Once I received - watched a couple of youtube videos to learn more about the paperwhite...  I downloaded some of the books I have on my original Kindle and I did like that I was able to group together by authors in my library but everything is in black and white so was not pleased with the visabilty of the screen and the books are so small, it's hard to find which I would like to read next - I was questioning my eye sight because the covers of the books with not only being black and white but seem blurry - not sure what that is all about - I thought I needed new glasses but just had my eyes check 2 months prior so cannot be the problem ... Mind you I have over a 1000 books in my library since I only use the Fire HD for reading so a large pain in the neck in finding a certain book.. I guess I am so used to the original Kindle Fire HD I have been using where once I purchase a book, it shows up on the first screen in color and easy to see and find books in my library.. Since I am home, I am back to downloading books to my original Kindle Fire HD regretting that I spent all of that money and I have been reading again from my original (only replaced it due to I was leaving for vacation this summer and after owning my original Kindle for 9 years, the battery life only lasts a couple of hours - other than that - a perfect Kindle)..I also had issues of the screen freezing for some reason so would have to turn off and on again to get it going and search for the book I was reading again.....Plus I accidently turn the page too high up near the top of the kindle and down drops the menu screen which for some reason I do alot.. Very frustrating...With being a big time reader and rather read every night before going to bed or if I happen to wake up during the night, usually around 3:30am, I read again for a while to fall back to sleep.. At night would place on the black screen but somethimes when turning the page, there is a flash of white before it turns dark again... I'm sure that isn't the greatest for your eyes...Was now thinking of purchasing another kindle - possibly the new Kindle Fire HD 8 tablet coming out middle of October .. As stated in my heading, I keep trying to Love this Kindle BUT can't stand it...Would like to return the Paperwhite but when I click on the 20% off trade in button, the Paperwhite is not even on my list of choices.. It is showing one of the Kindles that was purchased for a grandchild and my original Kindle Fire HD (certainly not parting with my trusty "Old Faithful" Kindle)..I am afraid to spend more money again and be disappointed...Does anyone have advice on which direction to go if I decide to purchase another??? regards, HeidiUPDATE:... Received an email from Amazon wanting to talk about my problem and dislike - communicated through emails and was told I can always do a trade-in on the New, barely read on Kindle.. (possibly only 10 books).. Paid $185.89 with tax ($175.37 exclusive of tax) including cover and charging dock..Will only return anywhere from $5 to $30 on a Amazon credit pus 20% off if purchase another kindle (maybe another $25 credit?)...SO IF ANYONE DECIDES TO NOT LIKE THEIR NEW KINDLE, BE SMARTER THAN ME AND RETURN WITHIN THE 30 DAYS ALLOTTED TIME FRAME....Amazon - that is bit of a disappointment to your customers..

text: Overall I am very satisfied with this device. I upgraded from the old 5th generation, so that makes a huge difference.(Let's see about the battery life, but I have my hopes up. My old one sometimes died in the middle of a book, so for me, it cannot really get worse...)The screen is amazing, it is super responsive, everything is super clear, and the warm light is an absolute plus! So far the Auto brightness sensor worked for me well, so overall The screen is amazing. Also, finally, we got USB-C!I think it works really well in daylight, there is no glare or fingerprints that I noticed on the screen. However,  I tried using it without the background lights at night with my bedside lamp and there is minimal glare, and you can see fingerprints from using the touch screen from some angles, which was a bit of a turn off for me, and it really makes me miss the page-turning buttons, but once I adjusted the brightness, or better, turned off the lamp, it was not annoying.Overall it is a great device, and all the above inconvenience is not a big deal, but honestly.... Why on earth would you put that power button there?! Am I the only one who likes to rest their pinky there?! I mean, ok, I already got used to the power button being there since it was the same on the 5th generation, but come on! After all these great upgrades, why?! Seriously, it feels like putting a mug's handle at its bottom. makes absolutely no functional sense.

title: Device is Great.  Newest OS SUCKS
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 22, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: The Kindle device is great - awesome battery life, tons of storage, easy to handle, and so much better than my old Oasis.  Device gets 5 starts.However, the latest OS version sucks. OS gets 0000 Stars-The endless scroll in the library is useless when you have a large number of books and want to quickly navigate to a certain area - the page numbers (in library, not books themselves) were much easier for navigation.-There are "ghost" books - you tap to download a book, it says it queued, looks like it downloads, and poof - looks like it never downloaded.  However, if you search for the title, you now have 2 versions of the book.-Collections do not show or act as they did in previous versions.  Not a big deal for me but in the Unofficial Kindle Help Facebook Group, it's the primary complaint.-Why are there thumbnails of the covers in list mode?  The Kindle is much less responsive in list mode with the covers than in previous OS versions with no covers.  And they take up more space so you get fewer titles showing in list view.-Not all covers download and show.  Not a big deal before when you didn't see covers in List view in previous version but is annoying now.Suggestion for future - have "not downloaded" as a filter.  I like having all my books downloaded so a filter to see which titles haven't been downloaded would be a huge plus.

text: This is only the 3rd Kindle I've owned.  The Voyage has always been my favorite, but this new one is pretty spectacular.I'm on week 5 and have not charged it yet and I'm a heavy reader, minimum of 1 hour per day.  I previously returned the 1st version of the Oasis because I couldn't make it more than 2 days without having to charge it and that was unacceptable for how much I read.  My Voyage gets a good 2 or 3 weeks between charges.  This new Paperwhite is even better than that.I saw complaints about the position of the power button.  I do agree, different placement of this button would be better, but so far I've only accidentally turned it off once.  I don't know if this is because I have a cover on it or not.The only thing I've missed from the Voyage is the haptic page turn buttons and only when I want to go back a page but this is minor and I'm adapting to it.I did expect it to be faster on the responsiveness but it's pretty much the same as my voyage.  It's fine for page turning, but if you are searching the store or when waiting for the book to open, it's slower than I thought it would be.  Again, not horrible, just thought it would be better.While I haven't charged it yet, I did put it on my wireless charger to make sure it would pick up with the cover on and that seems like it's going to be a pretty slick feature to have that I'm looking forward too.I would definitely buy this one again and would recommend it.

text: I've owned nearly every iteration of the paperwhite since it's inception (except the oasis which was far too expensive) and this one finally addresses all the issues with previous models. Not to mention they finally introduced Dark Mode with white text on black background, which is even better for reading in the dark.The screen and device are the perfect size and weight.No more bezel for lint and pet hair to get caught under.My favorite feature is the ability to disable the touchscreen (found in the top right ellipses menu while reading a book) which still allows you to swipe for page turns but you can bump the screen or even intentionally put your thumb directly on the screen without activating any menus or accidentally highlighting words. My dog straight up licked the screen and the page didn't turn!Though it's not a new feature I do love the ability to connect Bluetooth headphones or speakers for listening to my Audible collection. It's not necessary since I have the device specifically for reading but it's a really nice feature to have nonetheless.I don't think I'll ever need another kindle paperwhite ever again, it's that good.

title: Web Browser Is a Joke
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: The Good -1) Size is ideal ... perfect combination of being relatively small, thin, and light while still maintaining a large enough size for good readability.2) Has the feel and look of a well made, sexy product.3) Page turning function works nicely. Just swipe right to go to the next page, and swipe left to go back a page.4) Good menus for customizing font size, print boldness, back lighting, and brightness.The Bad -1) WEB BROWSER/INTERNET IS A JOKE. They indicate it is an "experimental browser". What in the hell does that mean??? I'll tell you - it means that it barely works or doesn't work at all. I mean, why would any REAL company, especially one as big as Amazon release such a utter piece of crap. I realize a browser is not the primary thrust of this product, but come on Amazon, if you can't develop a reliably working feature, just leave it out altogether. Don't mislead and frustrate your customers by incorporating a have-baked "experimental" internet browser in order to sell the product. BTW, I was a early adopter of Kindle back in 20012 that had a browser that was infinitely better than this piece of crap.2) Downloading ebooks and audio books from your local library is very difficult if not impossible. You certainly can't do it directly from the Kindle due to the worthless internet browser discussed above. Supposedly you can download them to your phone first, and then synch your Kindle to your phone, but I was not able to get this to work after making a reasonable effort. I'll give this product the benefit of the doubt and assume that with enough effort this can be done but it certainly isn't intuitive.Summary - if you have lots of money and are ok with exclusively downloading expensive books from Amazon and doing nothing more, I would definently recommend this product, but if you would like to access free books from your local library, and/or occasionally surf the internet, download basic apps, or get emails, look elsewhere.3)

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: Truly think about what experience you want, convenience from a tablet, or a book?
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I just bought a paperwhite (Dec 2021), my Samsung tablet drowned :-( and it kinda freaked me out that I didn't have my book.... lol. Thank goodness for the kindle app on my phone, bought me some time. I decided to take the plunge and get a paperwhite - no glare!!So, I have had a Kindle Paperwhite 32 GB $139 Signature Edition for about a week now, I am transitioning from a Samsung Tab A2 (which I loved).Here is my review...1) its awkward to hold as its SQUARE shaped where my Samsung Tab A2 was a rectangle.2) The ON button is small, like tiny, and on the bottom (not digging). Hard to feel for with any finger - I cant tell when I have the button under my finger.3) It doesn't really TURN OFF. it goes into what I call zombie mode, and will put a generic picture or the book cover of what you are reading on the sleep screen. To turn it off you have to hold previously mentioned tiny button and then it asks if you want to Cancel, Restart or Screen Off, not sure it actually turns OFF?4) Turning it back on at this zombie screen = you have to hit that hard to find button again. and because of the awkward size, you have to hold with both hands or it slides away from you. you cant get a grip on it because its too wide. Or at least I cant. Unlike with my Samsung, I just tapped the screen and it would come back on, I miss that.5) Going from a tablet with color - when looking at my book library, to black and white is difficult, I didn't realize that the shopping experience would be affected.6)  I dont see as many books being offered, the screen is small - only 6.8" I miss having dozens of books being offered up to me.7) The reading page aesthetic is different - and the transition isn't as soft as when you fold one page to another. Whole screen flashes black, and then the words fall into place. Because the screen is so small you finish reading a page fast, regardless how small you make the page. feels like I am constantly having a glare flashing at me... White reading screen it flashes black.  Dark reading screen it flashes white - really distracting.  With the Samsung kindle APP - animation was flawless.8) You need to really consider what you want from this, vs what you want from a tablet. I freaking miss my tablet, you cannot answer email on this... Books only. You cannot do a quick convenient internet search, gotta go to a pc or your phone9) Audible was not evaluated, I use my phones Audible or Chirp apps for this. I did notice though that it synced between audible and the kindle really nicely.  In two of my screen shots you can see its asking me if I want to advance to the most further part I had listened to.OVERALL  - I think its kind of klunky and I am thinking about sending it back. Honestly, its not horrible, but its not wonderful either.  Truly only PRO thing I can think of, is the non-glare and thats really nice. But it doesn't outweigh all the other cons... I'll be your friend and recommend going with a tablet.

title: Extremely Disappointed!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I own the very first and second Kindle and the first Kindle Fire. I absolutely LOVE the first Kindle Fire! Unfortunately, the place where one plugs in the cord to charge it just stopped working. I used to be able to jiggle it and it would work... alas, all good things must end ... and it did. This is why I decided to purchase the Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) and because it reminded me of the first Kindle. It worked okay the first couple of months then the pages wouldn't turn.. no matter what I tried. I tried shutting it down and restarting it, closing the book completely, and reopening it (now, THAT'S a lot of fun! Try finding your place again!) Eventually, it starts working again... until the next time that is. But wait, there's more....! I have a difficult time reading the small font without my glasses. I always read in bed and do not want to fall asleep with them on.. besides, it's uncomfortable anyway. Of course, you can set the font to a larger size but the largest is still very small and still blurry to read, furthermore.... even though I "Save" it before going back to my book, it still somehow manages to change back to the smaller font all on its own...! (Now, what's up with that?)  Next, one must watch where you turn the pages from. You have to be careful not to be too close to the top or you'll end up getting the drop-down menu for your troubles. It can be a hassle but it's not a deal breaker... just annoying. Now, on to the actual "Homepage", this shows your library and the books Kindle thinks you might enjoy among other things on that page and are EXTREMELY difficult to make out. The titles and authors are not easy to read even WITH my glasses on. The page itself just seems totally unorganized and helter-skelter. It's as though they are trying to put entirely too much information into too small of a space. As you know, The Paperwhite is in black and white which causes any artwork or photos on the cover of the books to just blend in with any writing ie. the title, and the author's name. Sloppy, sloppy, sloppy. It's just very difficult to read especially for me because I like to read a lot of books from the same author and when you cannot make sense of the artwork and cannot read the title or make out the author's name very well it can become very frustrating! So, when I think of the money I paid and, it was kind of expensive, I get a bit depressed especially because I've become accustomed to nothing but the best from the Amazon Kindle. Boy, did you guys miss the mark on this one! I hope this helps someone. I am a true, blue Amazon Kindle fan and have been since the very beginning but, this one is just a great big looser!Teri S

text: My old Voyage bought 8 years ago needed to be replaced after the touch screen stopped responding to touches, so I went with the Paperwhite 11th generation.  The user interface is much worse than what was on the Voyage.  The home page is very busy and confusing, and it is hard to find the content I'm looking for.  On the Voyage, the time was always displayed at the top of the screen even when I was reading a book.  On the paperwhite, you have to tap to a menu in order to see what time it is.  Extremely inconvenient.  On the Voyage, while reading a book, you just had to tap "Go To" to go to a different section of the book.  In the Paperwhite, "Go To" is hidden and more difficult to use.  These are not just a case of just needing to learn how to use different navigation, they are cases where navigation is simply more difficult to use.When reading a book on the Paperwhite, certain passages are underlined with a note telling me how many people have highlighted that passage.  This is extremely distracting and of absolutely no interest to me, and apparently there is no way to turn this feature off.I really miss my old, easier to use Kindle.

text: My first review still counts. Since my purchase in late November of last year I have read 50 books. That's forty-five more than my past averages. This Kindle makes it fun, and easy to read. However, one major complaint. And that has to do with the note-taking ability. If someone were to produce something like the Kindle Paperwhite with a note-taking ability that did not feel like you were watching a snail run the 100 yard dash I would buy it today, immediately. It is so frustrating to take notes on this Kindle. If you are in a book where you are taking many notes it may possibly double the time it takes to read the book. Very frustrating.Best investment in a long time. Sixty straight days of reading and twenty-two books read. It seems that over the past 3-4 years it was only 3-4 books a year. The Paperwhite has been a complete joy. I especially like that it constantly shows the percentage read in your current book. What a motivator. I bought the 32GB model. When???12/21/2021  Well, it's officially been back in stock for a few days now and still, I have no idea when I will get my replacement sent to me. At this point, Amazon has had my paperwhite longer than I got to use it.  I'm supposed to get an email when they have a shipping date.  Don't get me wrong, it was great when I was using it and I loved reversing the screen to white lettering on a black background for reading in bed. I'm just not impressed with the customer service or the Bluetooth being glitchy. Will update the saga later...01/09/2021  Ok, so I called customer service AGAIN. They decided to just give me a refund and told me to order a new one, wtf? You can't just ship the one you owe me? I waited to see the money back on my card. title: It's the best overall!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: My Kindle paperwhite gave out and I read 2-3 hours a day.  So I decided to try the 2021 Kindle Paperwhite Signature (32GB) Edition.  It is such an improvement over my 2018 Paperwhite!  The screen is so much bigger and easier to see.  It's lighter.  The battery lasts so long.  2-3 hours reading everyday and I only have to charge it every week to 10 days.  I bought the Amazon cloth cover, after I had purchased a PU leather cover from another brand, because the reviews from the Amazon leather cover were horrific.  I love the cloth cover, its easy to hold and keep a grip over.  This is the best Kindle so far, and I've had every kindle made.  I loved the Oasis, but I had one with the charging cover and the battery life was pathetic.  My only complaint is that you can't get it with cell downloading capability.  We have spotty internet that goes out for sometimes a week at a time and the last tme that happened I couldn't download any books and I about freaked.  Other than that, I love my new Kindle Paperwhite 2021 Signature edition.

title: Mostly Enjoy It
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on October 31, 2021
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I previously used an Oasis and bought this 6.8 inch Kindle Paperwhite 5 because I was very much not a fan of the asymmetrical design/feel of Oasis, but loved the larger screen. I do like this device very much, only two things I wish were different. 1. Page Turn buttons (maybe similar to Voyage), but no star off for that. 2. The On/Off button is on the bottom which often is where my pinky rest when reading, where most people's pinky would and this causes the device to inadvertently turn off unless I'm actively thinking of where my pinky is. It's such an obvious issue, with such an obvious fix (put it on the top where hands will never be resting). I will take a star off for this because it really does dampen the enjoyment of reading on this device.Pros...Screen is big and looks great.Symmetrical design feels more like a book than Oasis.Software has seen huge upgrade in last six months and this device has the new, much improved softwareWarm Light and Black background with white text option is great for reading at night.Cons...No page turn buttons.Due to its location, the power button accidentally gets pushed while reading way too often.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: Fairly good reader with serious design flaws
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on September 6, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: There's a lot to like about the Kindle Paperwhite but it fails spectacularly in a couple of ways that detract somewhat from the user experience.The main selling point for a dedicated e-reader is that it is easier to read than a tablet under a wide range of ambient light intensity and the Kindle seems OK from that perspective.A minor flaw is the tendency of the touch screen to sometimes flip multiple pages.  I have not yet determined exactly what gesture causes this but it's a bit frustratingA major flaw that is in my opinion a total design failure is the location of the power button.  What were they thinking?  The power button is on the bottom edge of the Kindle and it is almost impossible to rest the lower edge of the Kindle on a surface (eg: a table or even one's lap) while reading without accidentally turning the thing off.  That part of the design is inexcusable and I find it troubling that this 'feature' has been present in previous models but has not yet been corrected.

text: I must be honest about the battery. If you use the light (I find the light is useless if it is not on full #24.) the battery will be used up in 8 hours. So I guess if you do not use the light it will last maybe 48 hours which will work great for outdoor, beach reading. Reading anywhere you do not need to use the built-in light.  Also the lights are not any brighter than the 2019 basic Kindle or the 2018 Kindle Paper White.  You will have serious eye strain if you do not have the lights on when using this even with the built-in lights on fully.  The lights on this are not sufficient for reading in the dark. People who say it is great for reading in bed without disturbing your spouse will go blind trying to read in the pitch dark with the weak lights on this or any other Kindle reader.  If you want to read in bed with no lights you will need to use the Kindle app on your phone or tablet computer.  With adequate external lighting this Kindle is great for reading a huge improvement over every other Kindle reader.

title: Great until…
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on February 14, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: Bought my Kindle Signature PW, lured by the wireless charging, in May 2022. I traded in a perfectly good, properly working Kindle (previous generation) for it.As of December 2022, the device will not connect to the Amazon storefront. Meaning—I can’t buy or download new books on the device itself. Which also means Amazon y’all are losing my money.It’s February 2023 and I’m still dealing with this issue, a device that won’t connect to the Amazon storefront no matter what I do. I have tried wiping the device clean and starting over. Forgetting the Wi-Fi network and reconnecting. I even spoke to a rep on the phone and went through the exact same process with him. And my Kindle Signature STILL won’t connect.Good thing I have KU and can at least download a book via my phone, although I can’t actually BUY any book on the device itself.  It’s an annoying inconvenience and the reason why I can’t recommend this particular product. I love Kindles and Amazon, but am seriously considering moving to a different ecosystem or just reading on either my phone or iPad (not as ideal as an e-reader). I’m disappointed.

title: 5 steps forward! 1 step back
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on October 30, 2021
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I cannot speak about its battery life, as I just got it today - - but the screen is very nice. The processing speed is somewhat lacking, noticed it during setup, but this is a non-issue when reading books & frankly I'm hoping a dulled processor also means a better battery life. It almost has to. Right?USB-C....finally. I even emailed Amazon about this, let microUSB die! Less cables, less fuss...USB-C. This is long overdue, everybody knows it, enough said.They got rid of the lifetime basic internet connection. I tried to buy it & couldn't. Pretty sad, and that's my '1 step back' part. I hate anything that takes value, options away from the consumer.At the same time, 5 steps forward. A net gain of 4, which needs to be celebrated. This Kindle has a lot of good things, and if you're like I was, holding back & punishing manufacturers for continuing to use microUSB & other dumb things...now's a good time to stop. This eReader is great; objectively it seems to have nothing wrong with it. They just took some functionality away. They'll figure it out.I'm overall really happy with this Paperwhite, can't wait to use it more. If I discover anything else good or bad, I'll update my review accordingly.

text: I debated back and forth about buying a kindle for a while. As much as I love the feel of reading a physical book, I can't argue with the convenience of buying/renting digital books. Prior to my Kindle, I'd been reading ebooks through my library and I wasn't sure if the kindle was worth the investment when I could just read on my phone or iPad. Let me tell you, I have no regrets; the screen is much easier on the eyes and it's nice to have a separate device for reading. You don't have the distraction of other apps or notifications popping up while you're reading. The battery life is great! And it's so worth getting Kindle unlimited. Now I'm reading constantly and I love the convenience of being able to finish a book and immediately start the next in a series no matter where I am without lugging around a bag full of books. I received one of these for christmas, and noticed right away that the right side of the device was a little loose. If you pinched it, you could feel it flex and hear it creak. Within the next 3 months, though, with VERY gentle use (It stays on my night stand and I read a bit before sleep. The replacement has the same issue, but not as bad as the original kindle was on day 1. I'm hoping this one won't get worse over time, too, but I suspect it will. title: Does not connect to WPA3 encrypted networks
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: This device (and most kindles, as of Mar 2, 2023) do not support WPA3 encryption. Why is this important? This means that if you're travelling and the wireless network or hotspot available to you no longer uses the WPA2 encryption standard, you will be unable to connect your kindle device to the wireless networks that use the newer WPA3 standard (which I believe has been around since 2018). Chances that hotspots and access points at your airport or hotel uses the older standard is slim, given the new standard has been available for almost 5 years at this time. If you cannot connect, you cannot download new books on the go. This is a major painpoint that has frustrated my wife, who I bought this device for. This was in addition to other issues - syncing to further page read was not working (if she read from another kindle device or kindle app), and random restarts were all too common.

title: Awful 'upgrade' from my Voyage - UPDATED: Better after A LOT of tweaking!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2021
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I've owned a Kindle Voyage since launch, and absolutely love it. But I'm getting older, and wanted something a bit bigger, a bit more modern to enjoy my evenings reading. The new Paperwhite looked all fancy; Type-C and wireless charging, 6.8 screen, waterproof, all that cool stuff. So I bit into the hype and picked one up.Unfortunately, it's almost instant regret from me. The screen is SO washed out and almost blurry, compared to my pinsharp Voyage. They both have 300 resolution, but it seems the quality of the screen is much higher with the Voyage. I realise the Voyage was a premium product, but it's been so long since it was released, I figured the screen from that device would at least be replicated on the Paperwhite Signature, if not improved.I didn't buy from Amazon US (I don't live in the US, so had to import from a third party seller) so I've no option to return. All I can do is put this warning out to others. If you are a first time buyer, or coming from another Paperwhite, you may be happy with how it looks. But if you have a Voyage, I'd definitely recommend staying with that until they release something equally good to replace it, because the Paperwhite Signature most definitely will not.UPDATE: So after changing the settings many times, and downloading new fonts, I have made the screen 60% better, in terms of clarity and readability. I would say, I still don't think it's as good as my Kindle Voyage, but it is much better than it was before, and it's much easier to read. Is the Signature version worth the extra money? No, the extra functions aren't worth the extra charge, hence 3 stars not 4, but it's OK, I have it now and I'm comfortable to read on it.

title: A Nightmare for Library Books
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2023
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I got this primarily to read library books from the Multnomah County Library (Oregon). While it works well once I have the book, it is a confusing nightmare to get the books onto the Kindle and then again to return them. The book has to be located in the library's software, then taken out, then a special link clicked which takes one to Amazon to download it. Returning or renewing a book is still more complicated, and most of the time, there's no way I can find to get the book out of my Kindle's Library. If I take out a book a second time, the Kindle says the loan is expired until I go through a complex process on my computer (not the Kindle!) to re-enter it the loan into the Kindle's Library.Why this is so convoluted and always requires at least two devices and two or three different sites or software packages is beyond me. I suspect that it's because Amazon wants you to buy books -- and they make that easy -- rather than take them out from your library.The device is great for reading once a document is on it, but a hot mess if you want to take books from the library.

title: Not for reading one-handed
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 29, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: After a few years, my 10th gen Oasis has horrible, horrible battery life (as in, charge every few days!) so I gave this one a shot. The feature I was most excited about was the wireless charging - the idea of my book propped up, fully charged, always waiting to be read was irresistible.The wireless charging is nice, I’ll admit.Holding it is the problem. As one of the most “First-World” of “First-World Problems”, I can't hold this model of Paperwhite comfortably with one hand, which is a deal-breaker. Most of my reading is in bed, with the backlight on “1”, and I enjoyed the warmer light option with this model even though you really can’t tell a difference when there’s so little light. Although the specs show this to be a little over an ounce heavier than my Oasis, it felt like so much more, especially without a way to hold it comfortably. title: If you want text to speech get something else
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: WORST NAVIGATION OF ANY DEVICE I HAVE EVER SEEN.  I am a device junkie so this is not something I should have a hard time with. BUT. I already had an older Paperwhite. I had two reasons for being interested in this one: I can switch the background to black, with white print, for reading at night with the lights out, and to have a screenreader in the paperwhite instead of having to use the Kinde Fire when I want to listen. The Fire screenreader is easy and fine but I have sleep problems. I work with people who have disabilities and I am well aware of the need for accessibility features for people with visual impairments. However, the speech to text feature on this is completely designed for people with visual impairments and there are multiple multiple steps and taps and clicks to get it to work.  I like to be able to sit and read, and then if I need to get up and do some boring task, continue to "read" by switching to screenreader mode. This is accomplished in about half a second with the Fire. With this paperwhite, there are multiple steps, annoying clicks which are useful for the visually impaired, but there is no option for people without a visual impairment to quickly and easily switch to screen reader mode. For that matter - I went through an illness causing complete blindness and then gradually improving vision over several months, so I know what I am talking about: if I were in that situation now I would just use the Kindle Fire I got around 2014, learn how far from the bottom of the screen I need to tap to switch to speech-to-text mode and that's that.  Easy peasy. This Signature Paperwhite is easy UNTIL you try to change any setting or switch to the screen reader. In fact a person with a significant visual impairment would need major assistance from a sighted person to not just to set up, but continue to navigate this device, the accessibility menu is a farce. Turning the page is easy but going into menus the screen's sensitivity is variable, sometimes responsive and sometimes not. I wanted to love this but... looks like I will use it at night in bed and go back to the Fire for text to speech. New software should make things EASIER not harder. I cannot begin to tell you how bad the instructions and navigation are on this. Considering returning.

text: First, what I like about the new generation Kindle:- The longer battery life (from a week between charges to almost a month)- USB-C finally (Kindle was my last daily device stuck in micro USB land)- The auto adjusting backlight- The ability to adjust the temperature of the backlight (and to do so on schedule)But unfortunately the Kindle still has many of the annoyances of the previous generation.- While slightly faster, it can still sometimes freeze and become unresponsive, about as often as my prior gen device- The touchscreen will randomly become unresponsive, the only solution being to cycle the power- The touchscreen will randomly become over-responsive and turn a single tap into multiple- A cold boot takes FOREVER; potentially even longer than the prior gen- The damn power button being so inconviently located on the bottom, right where my finger wants to rest (and preventing propping it up; seems the top is r much more logical place)- A new problem: The narrower bezel means less gripping surface area on the sides, making this Kindle harder to read in bed one-handed (my preferred reading position)I hope some of this can be fixed with software updates, but those rarely seem to help much on this platform.

text: I've been a Kindle user for a long time and stopped using it when several of them in a row broke (when they had buttons to turn the page and the buttons would break after a few weeks of heavy use). text: This new Kindle is fantastic and is a very pleasing upgrade. I have had several Kindles, the second generation Kindle, a Paperwhite, a Voyage and then the 2018 Paperwhite. I love books, physical and digital. My preference for reading is always a Kindle since it can hold so many books. I was always frustrated however, by the slow interface. It took forever (well, it felt like forever) to turn on and load my book, turn pages and highlight text. I often would use my iPad or my phone to read since they were so much more responsive.  Well, no more. This new version of the Kindle (on top of having a larger reading area which is actually quite nice) is a LOT faster and much more responsive.  I am very much enjoying reading my books again on the Kindle.If you are considering a Kindle and you don't have one yet, BUY THIS. I haven’t missed the Voyage’s haptic buttons.  I know a few people do not like the placement of the on/off switch but I have not found it a problem. After a week, I haven’t once accidentally pressed it.This is my first kindle w/o cellular. I strongly encourage Amazon to improve the experimental browser.  I only use the WiFi/cellular for downloading books or Wiki definitions.  I was unable to connect to WiFi on Amtrak or at the hotel since their WiFi requires that you go to their web site & accept terms & conditions.  I thus needed to use the hotspot on my phone.  This is a clunky work-around.Overall, highly recommend this device.

title: Unintuitive interface, combined with incompetent customer service
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on February 28, 2023
options: Color: Denim | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: The device is incredibly slow and laggy over Wi-Fi. I have gigabit Wi-Fi all over my house, and the device takes several minutes to download audio narration for a file. The interface is incredibly unintuitive. Settings which should be at a readers fingertips are hidden under various sub menus, with no way to figure out how to get to them other than googling “how do I activate X feature on my Kindle?”I had a simple question regarding how to read a book while playing the narration at the same time. It’s a feature that is offered on the Kindle app, so it made sense that it should also be available on a full kindle device.  However, after being transferred between six different customer service representatives, not a single one of them was able to even make the slightest headway on the problem. One of them offered me directions to the Kindle app, which were obviously not relevant. Others told me to click on my screen and go to nonexistent menus, a process made even slower by Amazons ridiculous decision to not allow screenshots during its customer service chats. In the end I gave up, because the bumbling six stooges they sent had the stock reply to every question of “hold on, let me look that up.”  There wasn’t a single “technical service“ rep that had enough knowledge to be able to answer any questions straight up. A slow, laggy, unintuitive device made worse by poor customer service. If I could return it now, I would. Complete disappointment.

title: Still unreadable if light shining directly on it.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 24, 2021
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: The responsiveness of the new 11th Generation Kindle Paperwhite is very nice. No waiting when you turn pages or change settings.However, the screen is no more clear than the previous couple of generations. When a light is shining on the screen, you can actually make out the reflection of the source on the screen (light bulb or sun), and it is necessary to change the angle you are holding the device, or your entire reading position, in order to clear the visual disturbance.  This is a regression in light disbursement from the original Paperwhite screen and from that used on the Kindle Voyage. Both of those do a much better job of disbursing the light. I'm guessing they deemed this acceptable because of increased scratch resistance (or similar) of the newer screens. However, since the main point of the product is to allow easy reading in the sun or in rooms with bright lights, this seems a bad trade-off to me. This is the reason I have not bought a new Kindle in many years despite having dropped my previous, non-waterproof version in some water. The only reason this purchase isn't being returned is because I had some gift cards which were paying for a good portion of the price, lowering my personal expense. $180 is way too much for a device that is often still difficult to read.The 32G of storage is nice, though I will likely never use it all. Also, I like very much not having to see ads displayed on the screen when it's sleeping.

text: This is my 5th kindle. I read a LOT. So I have an extensive book collection.  I “upgraded” from the 7th gen to this because my battery is giving out (the problem with the previous kindles).  I should send this back, but my husband was so happy to buy it for me, I’m keeping it. What I don’t like:1. The screen is actually too big. I’m constantly accidentally barely touching the screen and it flips pages. There’s not enough room on the sides to hold it without touching the screen.2. The screen is tooooo responsive. I remember the 1st kindle without buttons, you had to almost punch the screen to turn the page. Can we have a setting for responsiveness???3. I’ve turned off the auto bright in settings, but it’s not actually turned off. Suddenly my screen gets really bright then dims slowly.4. There is NO way to turn off seeing book covers. I used to see 8-10 books per screen in the library. Now I see 4. If you use collections, you can’t see a list of the books, only the covers. It seriously is a pain to find my next book! Since I have ~300 books to be read, there’s no good way to browse like my last kindle.5. This isn’t Amazon’s fault, but Moko doesn’t make my favorite cover for this model. I had to buy 2 different ones & craft them together. I like the plastic back with a cover that has a stand.6. Yes, the on/off button DOES extend out enough to engage it when standing up. I have lap reader pillow to perch the kindle on, and the button engages every time!Bottom line, I wouldn’t buy this version. I’m seriously thinking of figuring out how to replace the battery in my 7th gen one.

title: For any UX people who are interested, here is my setup experience
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I tried to use the phone app to set it up, failed. So I manually signed in. My library was there and started downloading. I went to the store to buy some books. Unresponsive screen and false pickups caused me to unintentionally buy a book, then I was able to cancel it. Then I bought some other books. Some showed up in my library, others didn't. Then the device got stuck in a reboot loop. Kept trying to download a book then it rebooted. I had to unregister my device then re-register the device, this time the phone app worked to register it. That fixed the rebooting. Then I couldn't figure out why some purchases weren't showing up. I bought them again and they were marked as already being bought but didn't show up in Kindle. I couldn't for the life of me find order history for any Kindle stuff. Finally in my email I saw my Amazon card flagged it as suspicious and blocked it. After much effort I figured out that the order history has a filter already set to not show digital purchases. Then I set it on the wireless charger to charge and went out to dinner. When I came back the light was no longer solid but flashing and it barely charged.I am hoping that after this rough start the device will be better to actually use than to set up. The slow screen refresh makes it confusing and resulted in accidental purchases. Maybe reading will be better than the store.Update: once the initial issue of it constantly reloading the store then rebooting was solved by unregistering it then re-registering it the store has been usable on it and reading on it is really nice. I would give it 5 stars if the setup went smooth. I do recommend buying it and just be patient with the setup if you also have the software issue and credit card freeze. I am leaving it at one star so people can see the setup experience and know what to do if that happens to them and so they see that it is still absolutely worth getting despite the issues I ran into.

text: If you are like me and prop up your kindle as you read, this Kindle (and the model before this) will not work for you either. When propped up, changing hands, turning pages etc. the on/off switch randomly turns off as I am reading. I could not even set it up without triggering the bottom button which protrudes almost 0.5mm from the bottom.  If, like me, you had the idea that changing the page orientation might be a solution for the button issue, it is not. The page orientation only allows for the button to protrude from the bottom or the left side.  The open, uncovered (could this really be waterproof?) charging port is next to the button, so charging while reading is almost impossible. It is also more than 1 ounce heavier than the voyage which does not seem like much until you handle it and realize that it not as ergonomic as the voyage and that the device must be held because of the button issue.  Of course, the trade off is the screen, which is almost an inch wider and almost an inch wider than the Voyage.  Unfortunately, bigger is not always better and can be a real disadvantage if you want to throw it in a pocket or purse. The screen is extremely bright and even when changing the “warmth” it is slightly more blue-tinged than the voyage.  I was so excited to finally replace my beloved kindle voyage that is on its last legs, but alas this going to be my back-up travel kindle so I can keep my voyage as long as possible.

title: Software designer doesn't use the Kindle or read many books
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: Bought this kindle for my wife's birthday.  This is her 4th kindle.  She's been a user since the very 1st beta version of the Kindle.  She has enjoyed version she's had and happily used them.  She had to adjust to the smaller memory of a Paperwhite.  Now with this Signature Paperwhite she can have more books again.  She reads over 300 new books a year and her electronic book collection is over 8000.  She reads every day.  I lay all of this out to explain why she gave this kindle a 1 star.Whatever developer created this new software that she didn't have upgrade on her 2012 Paperwhite has only 1 goal in mind.  And that isn't to make it easy for a user to find their books and read it. It is purely to SELL BOOKS.  The home page which should be an easy screen to see the books she needs to review (she reviews for several reviewing sites and directly for publishers and authors), instead is focused on recommending books to buy or read.  Books that keep in mind, she has ALREADY READ due to her reviewing or she purchased.She doesn't need recommendations of books.  She needs to work through her books.  With a TBR Pile of over 1600 books and most of those she owns, wasting valuable space on the kindle to show recommendations only irritates her.  This birthday gift which was supposed to be a wonderful gift has now incensed her and she wants to get rid of this new kindle.But wait... there is the "library".  This is not intuitive.  So once again, the developer has zero concept of using a kindle for heavy reading.  I did mention she has thousands of books, right?  Whilst the collection feature is nice, she wanted to only load some of her books that she wants to focus on in her library.  Now, random books have been downloaded from our family collection and is cluttering her kindle.  She can't find the book she wanted to read.Before anyone claims my wife is a technophobe, she's in IT and has designed websites, graphical user interfaces (GUI), and other cloud SaaS applications.  Whilst the hardware of this Kindle is great.  The software is absolute garbage and the software development team should either be fired or receive a massive paycut.  Maybe next time, have programmers that are heavy readers actually try and use the software before rolling it out.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: Pokey and only good for reading
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2021
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I bought this device to alleviate eye strain and I’m comparing it to my experience using an iPad.  So, the paperwhite is basically a book and it has very limited functionality aside from a pure reading experience.  It’s for people who have a few books they are loyally making their way through without interruption.  It has also imported my wishlist as a “reading list”.  That would be fine if I were using the wishlist as an uncomplicated TBR list.  However, I have a KU subscription and usually have 20 books I’m reading, started, or am about to start.  That means I do a lot of looking at book details to remind myself what the book is and where I am in it.  It also means I look for books a lot.  Similarly, I don’t use my wishlist as an uncomplicated TBR list.  I use it as a way to track books in preorder.  So my wishlist is carefully ordered by publication date and I can easily see which book is still in preorder and what has come out.  I also have comments on the books to remind myself what they are and what my thoughts were on the series.  In the Paperwhite, the list order is destroyed and you can’t tell if the book is on preorder or what the publication date is.  You also can’t see the comments you’ve made. So, the reading list is useless for me.  I think it has helped my eye strain.  I can use it when I start binge reading books or series.  That’s good.  But it’s not going to be my favorite device.  It’s like reading glasses.  Something you’d forget, if possible, but are forced to use because your eyes $uck.  If I could configure the Kindle app and my iPad to be better on my eyes, I’d dump this device in a hot second.  As is, I still use it.  Also, it’s crazy slow.

title: Kindle is ruined
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: Why is Kindle operating system now such a pain? I was an early adapter of this e-reader and have adored it over the years. It’s joy was in its simplicity- intuitive to use, quick to switch between store and library. But over the last couple of years it’s become slower, quirkier and clumsier to buy new books or access material you already own. I swear it takes 3-4 more touches to make a purchase than it used to. And it is constantly sending error messages, “Kindle store temporarily not available” and the like. I’d think it was because it was an older device, but I actually own 6 paper white, oasis, and now this 2022 edition. Unfortunately, the older, simpler devices automatically load latest operating versions, so they are uniformly as irritating as the newest version. Screen lighting, battery life, and wireless charging stands are improvements, but actual operating system has gotten worse over time instead of better. It no longer even has a words/list only version so you are forced to see illegible book covers which only serve to take up more screen space and cause you to make more screen swipes. Never thought I’d do it, since I own thousands of titles on Kindle, but I’m going to buy a Nook or other e-reader because I’m so frustrated and disappointed with how Kindle has gone downhill. Anyone else frustrated?

text: My last Kindle was getting on in years and would periodically freeze and need to be reset and the battery wasn't lasting as long. I've only had it a few weeks and I have to restart it several times (and restarting takes forever).  The worst part though, is they took away all of the book organization that I liked.  I got one with tons of storage thinking I could leave all my books downloaded, but it's way too messy now.  Before I kept all of the books that I read over and over downloaded in collections (listed first) so they'd be available even if I was offline (camping, etc). Then all the books that I had downloaded to read or kept for other reasons were listed after the collections. Now, they show up individually in the library even if they're also in collections.  There's no way to 'tuck them away' so it's chaotic and difficult.  It's either remove the download, or have a disaster of a library listing.  What's the point of buying a kindle with extra storage space then??  And just a small thing, but my old library had "page 5 of 45" etc when I was scrolling through, and now there's nothing to indicate how many 'pages' are in my library.  If I could buy the same one I got five years ago, I would do that instead after spending a few weeks with this one.

text: I've bought every kindle they've released, including the Oasis, and this by far is my favorite. I was also never fond of the metal backing, and I prefer to use my kindle's without a case.  Now that they've released this edition, it has everything I could want and is the perfect model for me. location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on November 22, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: So far, I can't say I'm very impressed. I purpose bought the Kindle for reading documents on other than my iPhone while traveling.  Reading paperbacks and novels is secondary - I actually prefer hard copy.  I was hoping this device would be an answer to the stack of PDF, DOC, ePub, and HTML docs I review on a daily basis.  Unfortunately, Amazon's claims exceed the beef. The browser is painfully slow when it works at all. The PDF utility basically displays a "miniature PDF page" that requires a spyglass to read  ...How about reformatting it to fit the device? I have yet to try the other "supported" personal document formats, but so far Amazon's Kindle appears to be nothing but an ebook reader with a lot of smoke-and-mirror claims.  Can I get my money back?

title: Customer Ripoff
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on July 9, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: This is my third Kindle. After you have sold your book collection, and have been using one of these for over 10 years, you are stuck. There are many things to like about this new version. But everyone else has talked about them.This is why I gave this new 2022 iteration a rousing 1 star. There is no cord that comes with this device. If you want the cord that fits the port, you will have to buy one for about $10. This port is different from your other Paperwhite, if you had one, so your old cord and charger will not work. That is listed nowhere in the product description. Moreover, you will also have to buy a charger for another $20. So slap $30 onto the price of this baby.When you do go to purchase said cord and charger, good luck choosing the one that is right for your new device. Amazon has gotten away with one of the most feeble search bars on their website for years. Just try finding the right cord and charger for this new Kindle. You will get pushed a bunch of cords and chargers that are all wrong for you. It took a customer rep from Amazon, and I, about 20 minutes trying to find the right ones. And, honestly, I think we may have gotten it wrong. I went back and ordered a different cord and charger today to be sure. Because I believe he chose the 2021 cord and charger. Even the Employees of Amazon can no longer accurately choose the right products that work with Amazon devices.So, for the inflated price, the ridiculous add-ons, the sloppy marketing and website, and the fact that any customer who reads with frequency will have to buy a new device every 5 years, because their Kindle battery will fail, and has that obsolescence built in, I have subtracted 4 stars. I wish I could have subtracted 10.

options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I purchased this kindle because of the audiobook feature. I was very excited about this, but much to my disappointment the technology is still lacking tremendously. Personally while listening to the audiobook, I like to read along with it. While using the kindle app on my phone, if I own the audio version and the kindle book version, not only can I use both at the same time… but it highlights the words as the audiobook reads them also changing the pages automatically as the audiobook reads. This is fully what I has expected from this kindle! However, there is no way of listening while reading along at the same time on the kindle. I can’t imagine how they are lacking the technology to allow this. text: I just got this Kindle Paperwhite in January 2022. It lasted just over a month (we're at the end of February 2022 right now). I'd bought it when my previous Kindle Paperwhite from April 2020 died. When THAT one died Amazon offered me a new one with a 15% discount. I pointed out that it was pretty lame that I was only getting 15% off when the device I was replacing had only lasted about a year and a half. They relented and gave me 30% off. So, I took the 30% discount and bought this Kindle... which has stopped working at just over ONE MONTH OF USE. Amazon is sending me a replacement that won't get here until the end of March or early April. They're giving me a $10 gift card for the inconvenience... ugh. Whatever. There's nothing I can do about it. I'd leave Kindle if I weren't so invested in all of the digital books I own in this format. So, beware: I've had two of these late model, waterproof Kindles crap-out in a pretty short period of time. Amazon has done the bare minimum to make it right. I cannot recommend buying a Kindle Paperwhite. I'm feeling kind of screwed by Amazon right now. Ah well. I hope this helps. Please note: the attached pictures show what my broken Kindle does. It just goes back and forth between the logo screen and a blank screen. I guess it's trapped in some kind of reboot loop. That's it. Ugh.

I finally purchased one, waited forever for it ship, and enjoyed about 4 months of using it. I didn’t use it much as I wound up getting Covid and some other excuses. A few weeks ago, mine bricked itself. It’s stuck on the screen where someone is reading under a tree. No reset, different charger, or any other “solution” I read in any of the support groups or was offered by customer service.I have spent several hours on the phone with customer service which thinks we’re all idiots (or so it seems). They promise to send a brand new one since mine is under warranty and it’s not an issue I caused (it’s a well known hardware issue apparently). I now have two refurbished ones that are marked “refurbished” on the box before you even open it. This whole thing has been a joke. I can’t use the kindle, get lied to by customer service reps, and now I can’t take it on a trip that I would love to read on. No one should be satisfied with receiving a refurbished one (and I’ve read horror reviews of people who had to go through this same bricking crap with their used replacement models until they finally gave up). options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I have been a Kindle user for years.  I started with the Kindle 3rd gen, now known as the Kindle Keyboard. Since then I've had 2 other Paperwhites and 2 Fire Tablets. I didn't really need an upgrade but they got me with the 32g, USB-C, wireless charging,warm light,  autodimming plus I traded in for a discount. End of April, my new Signature arrived, not well packed, big streak down the screen. Nice.  Chatted with support, replacement sent,  cool.  My new one arrived 3 days later,  great, I'm happy,  started setting up.  I do wish there was an easier way to transfer your library. I have a lot of books and Audible content and it takes a while to tweak everything like I like it,  but minor complaint honestly.  I'm happy,  it's fast and page turns are great. Love the warm light and autodimming, really enjoying. May 10, my kindle blinks, resets and is stuck on the boy under the tree screen.  I tried every trick known to get it to hard reset, no luck.  Contacted support. They were again great and are replacing it. But I've owned this device less than a month and when it arrives it will be my third one in that time.  My Kindle Keyboard still works. I've dropped my prior Paperwhites from heights with no damage. My Fires have taken direct hits from my kids,  no problem. What I'm saying is they aren't delicate devices like the iPad, which is why I like them as my daily driver reader to go everywhere. They just work. But like,  3 in 3 weeks? I'm worried. Will update when the new one arrives.I was happy with the device when it worked, screen was great,  loved the features, no complaints. Amazon support has been great.  I just am worried about the quality of the device/software here...

title: HW is OK, SW is Useless
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I have had Kindles for many years. I also have more than 5K books on it. I understand that SW gets upgraded. I worked in IT for many years. HOWEVER, a prime precept is that new SW be better than the old. The developers obviously don't read books. I hate the view of the covers but I'll ignore that one since you can switch to a list. What I REALLY HATE is the scroll bar. Previously you could 'go to' an author or title. Now you have to scroll up/down with a bar that is too small and too sensitive to be of any use. Why can't you go directly to what you want. Also the screen is so sensitive that if you accidentally touch it wrong it jumps to the end of the book. There is no way to get back to where you were reading without manually going through the chapters until you find your place. I don't know about you, but I don't remember what chapter I was in. Also, in many cases it takes multiple tries to 'remove download'.  This is just a few of my complaints about the interface. I have looked on other forums and there are many others who feel the same. Why didn't you do a 'usability' test prior to the release? If you will notice, I have purchased many fewer books since the SW release. It's just too much trouble.

text: I bought this specifically for the automatic brightness controls, only to discover that it was designed by idiots.E-ink is designed to be readable in daylight. You don't need a backlight during the day. At night, the backlight is needed. Simple, right? Well, the Kindle Signature does the opposite. It turns the brightness UP when the ambient light is bright, and down when the ambient light is low. What kind of idiot designed that? The sensor should disable the backlight, saving battery, when there is sufficient light to read already, and turn the backlight to your preferred setting when the room is dark. Easy!Save your money and buy the cheaper model unless you really need wireless charging, the automatic brightness control is a broken feature.

options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: The Kindle Signature is my 7th Kindle.  I bought it and the charging stand as soon as they came out because my last Kindle was dying.  I waited over a month to receive them.First, the Kindle was no where near as smooth working as my others have been -- always trying to "update my Kindle experience" and making mewait before it connected to the store or even show the main screen when I opened the cover.The charging stand is superfluous as it turns out -- it only works as a charger for this particular Kindle -- no others -- and will not wirelessly charge any other equipment at all -- and the Kindle itself charges on a regular USBc cord.Then my brand new Kindle died.  About a month into owning it -- it died.  I waited several week to get a replacement as, I guess, a big demand for these over the holidays.  I received the replacement today and tried to charge it using the Charging stand and found out that that no longer worked either!Amazon will send out a replacement of that in about a month.  -- another wait for this "signature" equipment.  I have a feeling that they will want to take the name "Signature" off of this model and charging stand because it is sure ruining my love of my Kindle experience.Summary:  In my opinion, stay away from this charging stand -- it is completely superfluous and clutters up table tops.  The "Signature" Kindle?  No, just no.  Buy a regular Kindle 10th edition -- surely that works better than this mess.Wishing you good reading and a different experience than I just had over the past two months.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: The new software is a step backward and needs a fix
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: Despite the impressive memory in this new kindle the current software only allows 21 items to be on the Home Screen. So you can only have 21 books or newspaper issues on the device.Prior software versions allowed more on device storage.Pick these 21 things carefully because the only way to remove them is by adding a new one that bumps off the oldest. “Remove download” previously removed a book or issue from the device but now it only eliminates the text. The cover image remains.I read a daily newspaper on my kindle and could previously remove issues after reading them. Now my Home Screen  fills up with read back issues and all the books get bumped back to the cloud.After 21 days there are no books on my kindle.I can find them again in the cloud but it is a bother and they are then just queued up to be bumped off again.I got this paperwhite 11th gen because my 7th gen got this software update and became a pain…prior software allowed more books on the device…I could schedule future reads and they would be waiting…I could remove completed books or issues. Customer service suggested I purchase a new device as a fix but they were mistaken.Many service calls about this issue were tedious and unhelpful.The current software on the phone app is much more functional. Books and issues can be shuffled around easily. “Remove from home” is an option.But I like the reading experience on the kindle better.Please, Amazon, issue a software update to restore the lost functionality.

title: Beware Bricked Software Defect in 4 months!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 4, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: Beware the brick reboot of death on the newer kindles! This seems like a firmware design problem - after owning this less than 4 months, it just started an endless reboot cycle and never gets past the boot screen (with the kid under the tree).  ‘Hard-reset’ doesn’t do anything, and there has been no damage / drop to the device.  Looking online, this does appear to happen to this latest generation of devices.  Cross your fingers and hope it happens in the warranty period (90 days)!.  I had to emphasize to customer support that this had to be a software problem, or a design defect with the power button continually pressed in a bag.  As an engineer, if I had to guess, holding down the power button continuously can cause the device to hard boot in the middle of a reboot causing an un-bootable state.I’m normally a big fan of kindle devices, but this is really unacceptable.  I hope engineering gets ahead of this and fixes it in a future generation.(Update) After arguing with the Amazon customer service reps, they ultimately replaced the kindle.  I caught a similar behavior recently on the new device, but managed to avoid the brick.  I don’t have a case, and if you set the device down standing up, it will trigger and hold the power button, causing a repeated hard-boot, including hard-boots in the middle of hard-boots.  Bad design.  I’m leaving this as 1-star for awareness and encouragement for Amazon to fix the design defect (even just via software).

text: I've had this Kindle for a few months and it is not good.Pros:. The battery lasts a long time.. The wireless charging is really nice, especially since the power port is usually the first part of a Kindle to have problems.Cons:. This is my first Kindle with a screen that's easily scratched. They're light scratches, but they're permanent. All I did was put it in my purse.. It can't be held from the top of the screen. The border there is only about 1/2 inch and I'm constantly activating the menus. Constantly.. It's already gone dead for no reason, a problem I've only had on older Kindles after a couple years of use.  Rebooting fixes it but I shouldn't have to do that. I went to bed with it at 60% and woke up to the battery screen on.. The position of the power button means that sometimes when I put it on the wireless charger, it turns on.. A large number of books on it slows it down considerably. I bought the version with more memory, but processing hasn't improved since the older models.All in all, this is not worth spending extra money on.Update 5/25/22: They managed to make this Kindle even more unusable with their recent software update that changed the whole file system. No way to get rid of ads completely (even though I paid for it), no way to hide collections that aren't favorited, and no way to go back to the older version. I'm a long-time Kindle user, and they're making me hate them.

text: My biggest complaint for over a decade is that instead of the kindle turning on to the title and book cover of the book I paid anywhere from 9.99 to 14.99 to read  it opens to an add.  Is Amazon so greedy and misinformed that after buying only kindle books since the first kindle was released they still try to sell me on titles I don’t buy? With this kindle , several new updates over the last year have made it nearly impossible to find the cover of the book I’m reading or just finished.  The image of the books I’ve read are so tiny it’s often impossible to read the title or author.  I want a real book type experience where I see the cover of the book I’m reading everytime I open my kindle. Instead Amazon uses it as an opportunity to sell more, sell more sell more. advertising books and authors I have no interest in. Hasn't Amazon made enough profit of off us? Isn’t enough I buy my books and kindle, groceries and gifts, household items and much more? Just let me read in peace without an add every evening when I open my book to relax. Absolutely nothing is worse than having to hunt for the book cover.  The familiar joke with my fellow kindle readers is we can’t easily recall author and title because we see it once during purchase. Tricky advertising diminishes my joy of reading on the kindle.
