title: Paperwhite Signature returned…
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on November 13, 2021
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: Nov 2021: After waiting months, the Paperwhite Signature arrived today. This replaces my Oasis 10th generation (2019). The size is perfect, it’s easy to hold and feels nice in my hand especially with a cork Amazon case. I don’t miss the Oasis page turning buttons, I never liked the clicking sounds of the buttons. The backlights are easy on the eyes with easy to adjust brightness and warmth, just like the Oasis. One feature I miss is the auto-rotating of the Oasis. The position of the page does not follow the rotating of the Paperwhite. The USB-C charger is a definite upgrade. The power button is on the bottom, just a little off-center. I don’t think it will be an issue while holding the Paperwhite to read.  I like it much better than the Oasis. If you want one, or think you might want one one, order it now because it takes months to arrive.Update Dec 2021: Returned this Kindle today. There were issues with constant page freezing, locking up Kindle. Frequently received error messages saying that ‘application’ was unavailable. The issues continued even after many restarts and system resets. I’ve owned many Kindles over the years and have never had these sort of quality issues before. Buyer beware!

options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: For years I had the Kindle Keyboard and never had a problem. Until about October of last year (2021) it finally gave up the ghost and stopped working.  The Kindle Keyboard was so I bought a Paper White and for a while it worked fine for a while.  But, just recently froze-up and now is stuck on Waking-Up.  So now I’ve got a useless Paper-White.  Luckily I’ve got the Kindle app on my iPad with all my books.  I won’t buy another e-reader but I will continue reading on my iPad.  Lesson learned.  The more they try to “improve” the Kindle the more things can go wrong.  But I do miss the Kindle Keyboard!04/23/22: supplemental update—- within 1 day after I posted my negative comments I got a call from Amazon customer service she tried to get my paper white Kindle running but it turned out the battery was defective so they offered to send me a new one and I got it within 2 days.  I can return the old one in the same shipping box .  As I have no way to print the return shipping label on my iPad she offered to send me a hard copy, should take about week or so to receive it. So I’m now playing a waiting game.  So far I’m happy with the customer service department.05/01/22 update: my new paper white Kindle works as good as I could hope for— great customer service, fast turnover for replacement.Last Ranger

text: I thought this would be perfect. I had an old Kindle HD Kindle but the battery lasted only about 15 minutes. I only ever read on it so thought I would just get a Kindle Paperwhite. Worst decision ever! Yes, the battery is good and it is fine to actually read on but every time you turn the page the screen flashes. It takes so long for the menu to respond you think it did not register and touch it again but then it registers both touches and takes you some place you did not intend to go.  Normally when you search you can go into one book or series in the list, then you select the back button to go to go back to your search list, but with the Kindle Paperwhite, that is not how it works. You go back to the original list and have to do the search all over again. When you scroll it sometimes take you into a book instead of the next page, loosing your search yet again. It is the most frustrating device for our times. We are so advanced, why would they make a device that It is like trying to get online with a modem and that flickers like flipping channels on an old black and white TV? I now do all my research on my laptop or iPad to figure out exactly what I want and send to the kindle and hope it comes through. This way I have to go through a few clicks to get to the book, but you should be able to do more. The only plus is the size and weight. That is the only reason to use it.  Otherwise stick to your other devices. I would return it if I could but I waited to long and it was a gift. Maybe I got a dud and should have tried to return it but assuming this functionality is normal I do not recommend for anyone who expects a responsive device or has trouble with flashing every time you turn a page.

product_name: Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition (32 GB) – With a 6.8" display, wireless charging, and auto-adjusting front light – Without Lockscreen Ads – Black
title: My Reading Headaches Are Gone! *literally*
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on January 15, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I hesitated to buy a Kindle for a very long time to my ruin.At first, I didn't understand why I would need an e-reader. After all, I have a phone and tablet that have great ebook apps. Wouldn't having a device dedicated to electronic books be a redundant waste?Then, I realized that all my attempts to read on my devices resulted in my eyes straining, my head aching, and my mind unable to focus. I bought paper books whenever I could, but a lot of my research materials for work could only be found in digital format. I had no choice but to read ebooks, so I needed to find another solution.And that solution was to buy a Kindle.PROS- The e-ink technology of the screen makes a dramatic difference in my reading experience.I can read for hours without the strain and headaches that a traditional screen would cause. I'm kind of addicted to reading on my Kindle now.- I love being able to discover new books and instantly download them. No more waiting for paper books to be delivered.- Highlighting is so easy.- The battery life is amazing.- The Paperwhite is super lightweight, compact, and easy to hold. I have a connective tissue disorder and holding books can sometimes aggravate my joint and nerve pain tremendously.In fact, I stopped reading a giant, 900-page book several months ago because my hands just couldn't take holding it anymore. I downloaded it as an ebook on this device and might be able to finish it now!CONS- E-ink screens flash black every so many pages or when you tap on to any new screen/menu. At first, I thought my device was broken. But, no, what looks like a full-screen glitch is important to its functioning.Initially, it bothered me, but then I eventually got used to it.  Now I barely notice at all.- The touchscreen has a very slow response. It makes me feel like I'm using technology from 10 years ago, instead of a brand new 2021 release. I like the taking notes feature, but the touch response is so slow that it picks up only half the letters I type.- If you send PDFs or other documents to your Kindle, it can take a long time for them to show up.- It can't run apps. Also, it has a web browser feature that is the slowest thing on the planet. Again, it makes me feel like I'm using dial-up instead of high-speed wifi.OVERALLThis e-reader has saved me from headaches and nerve pain. It is a pleasure to read on. Also, it's very cute.However, its touch screen technology and processing speed will make you feel like you time-traveled to the past.For me, it fulfills a serious need I had and the pros outweigh the cons. Of course, everyone's situation is different.

This is my first kindle and WOW I’m blown away by the construction and many many features and battery life and screen size/clarity. text: I have a pdf copy of a large textbook with dense print, as well as the physical copy. Between the feature that removes excess margins, and the 300dpi resolution, I’m able to actually read the book with some minor squinting. This is a huge improvement from my previous 200something dpi paperwhite (plus smaller screen) which was completely unusable for these kinds of denser texts. I do wish the screen was about an inch larger personally, but this definitely works! Also it is able to display the table of contents in PDFs as well as allowing you to select and search for word definitions, again two features that make this a very useful companion to large textbooks on the go. For some reason Amazon still blocks you from downloading many non-pdf kindle store purchased textbooks onto the device. That is a bit perplexing since they probably actually work on this device. Maybe a suggestion for future improvement would be to allow textbook download onto kindles that have a minimal screen resolution and/or screen size, this particular device being allowed. options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: So I was having a few adult beverages and browsing Amazon. When I saw they released a new generation of the Paperwhite, I thought "Sure, I need one of those". The truth of the matter was I really didn't NEED it, but I'm sure glad I purchased it.I'm a fan of the Paperwhite and I've owned the two previous generations. I read almost exclusively on it. When I ordered this one, it wasn't due to ship for about six weeks, but there was no urgency. To my surprise, it shipped a lot sooner (about three weeks), and it was worth the wait.I kept my previous generation Paperwhite, so it's interesting to compare the two. This new one is slightly bigger which is nice. It's still really easy to transport in a large pocket. It also has an auto sensing back-light which works really well in all light conditions. The other thing I like is the ability to adjust the warmness of the screen. If you're adverse to the really "white" back-light, you can adjust it to a much warmer tone. It's also worth mentioning that the battery life is excellent. I've been reading it daily for almost two months and have yet to charge it.Bottom line is if you're in the market for a Paperwhite, just buy this one. If you already own one. I still think you'll be impressed with the new features. Amazon offers a trade-in program for your old one if you want to save a few bucks. I hung on to mine for a spare. Buy without hesitation, you won't be disappointed.

text: I bought a Kindle Voyage in 2014 and it was pretty perfect - so much so that I simply had no reason to replace it especially given the former paper whites all ran at 226 ppi and my Voyage was 300 ppi.  Recently the battery was beginning to fail and I knew it was time to make a change.  I saw this new kindle and didn’t have to think about it for long.  Better battery life, 300 ppi, a slightly larger screen (love this).  My kindle arrived quickly and first impressions were that the build quality is noticeably better than any of the recent units - it was much more like my Voyage.  I’m impressed.  I’ve been reading non-stop since it arrived and the battery life is impressive.  This is a winner folks.  I’m so glad I bought this one.  I’m sure this kindle and I will be friends for a long time! text: My ancient Kindle has died. I was really upset but on the other hand it was 10+ years old. The only other thing I’ve bought was my van and it’s 32 years old.I spend a lot of time reading and I am anticipating years of use with my new Paperwhite. I had quite a library of books I kept as reference on the old Kindle. They were all easily transferred to the new one with room to spare. It was suggested I use the IOS program on my cell phone to make the app do all the work. Wow!! Was that easy. Then I updated the software using the new Kindle. That was easy too!! Having a touch screen is fabulous too. The old Kindle version had a keyboard. If I wasn’t careful about eating/not eating while using it the keyboard could get sticky. In fact that was what I thought was wrong with the old Kindle at first and cleaned the screen and keyboard (using a needle to scrape/dislodge gunk around the keys). Alas, something else was going whack with the old Kindle. I mourned a couple of days thinking all my books were lost and then investigated to see what Kindles were available and their cost. I was delighted to see I could make monthly payments on the new one. I think I should have gotten the case to protect it too. I’ll order it later.

text: I've used previous versions of the Kindle and the Kindle Paperwhite.  This newest version is the best one yet.  The improvements to clarity and speed of the pages are impressive.  It's the perfect reading tool, especially for bedtime reading.  I was hesitant to upgrade from the 2019 version since that one does everything I need, but when my daughter gave me the newest version for Christmas, I was upgraded and am very happy.  So why give it four stars?  Unlike earlier Paperwhite models, there is no option to get cellular service for the Paperwhite - so it depends on wifi only for connection.  I wouldn't mind paying a few $$ extra but it's just not an option for the newest Paperwhite. If you need to download a new read while stuck at a location without wifi, you are out of luck.  This is especially a problem when traveling.  I still have my earlier version with cell so I'll take that with me.

text: I love this purchase. I use it all the time. With my eyes deteriorating with age, this has become my favorite way to read.The battery life is very good. I have a lot of books, and I'm slowly downloading everything in case of an Internet outage.The screen is excellent. The size of the device is excellent. The only complaint about the physical device is that the button on the bottom is a little too easy to accidentally press, which puts the device into sleep mode. I do this from time to time, and must wait a few seconds while it wakes up again. It's bad design, but not a killer for me.I love that it can be charged wirelessly. I almost never use the stand to do this, but that's a personal quirk. I do use the stand to hold the device while I read, and it works well both with the flip cover open and when the cover is tucked behind the device.I had been using a phone and sometimes a tablet to read before purchasing this device. It was fine, and I had had some doubts as to whether I needed yet another doodad, but I'm very glad I got this.

title: A Life Changing Purchase
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: In 2020 I purchased the 2018 Kindle base model, and it offered a pleasant experience with a simple form factor at a low price (I believe I bought it for around $60 on Black Friday). To my dismay, the very next year I discovered that they'd released this incredible piece of technology. At nearly $200, I felt I should wait until a sales event, so I bought it as a birthday present to myself on Prime Day 2022 for around $139. This is easily the best purchase that I have made within the last 12 months, and top 5 within the past several years. Not only does the warm light option greatly soothe my eyes, but the size is more substantial than you would assume. It's as similar to reading a physical book as I think e-readers will get anytime soon. Before my Kindle Paperwhite Signature was delivered, I read about 5 books from January-July. In the 2 months since it arrived, I've completed 13 books. It's worth noting that I've always been a physical book person for all the usual reasons (book smell, feel, aesthetic, etc.) And this device has converted me. The portability is incredible, the 32 GB storage capacity is breathtaking (although I don't imagine ever coming close to it seeing as I don't listen to audiobooks or other large files), and the screen resolution in comparison to the 2018 kindle is definitely noticable. I cannot tell you how elated I am to Finally be allowed to put micro-USB behind me in favor of all USB-C charging devices. I'm in love with this piece of technology and would easily count it as my most valued inanimate possession.

title: A well designed device

options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: This unit was a replacement for my old Keyboard Kindle that I have had for the last 10 years. I still have it and will keep it although the battery only holds a charge for 24 hours.Touch ScreenThis took some time to get used to but I like it.  I did not like having to touch it with my finger and leave smudges on the screen.  I found it works well with an electro-conductive stylus, eliminating the need to touch the screen with my finger.  Even though I like the touch screen, I preferred the buttons on the Keyboard unit. I considered getting an Oasis but there were a lot of negative comments on battery life so I passed on it.  The one thing I do not like with the touch screen is that it is very easy to touch the screen in normal use and wind up a page of two away from where you want to be.Battery lifeSo far, I am happy with it.  I want to see how long the battery lasts if I keep the WiFi turned off unless I need it.  Battery life was the primary reason I bought the Paperwhite, in that all the reviews were good regarding the battery.  I had to use Airplane Mode to shut the WiFi off where as the Keyboard unit had a WiFi off/ on option on the home screen.ReadabilityI like the Paperwhite's sharp text and white background.  I also like the screen backlight.  Many times I will read at my workstation where the ambient light is low for image editing.  The backlit screen on the Kindle is perfect here.OverallI find that I rather like it after the initial period of "Where did they put that"? I like the wireless charging as well. I hope it lasts as long as my first Kindle.

title: I compare my experience with the Kindle Paperwhite, Oasis and Special Edition
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on August 11, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I've owned three different Kindles and here's my comparison and what I liked about them:I got the Kindle Paperwhite back in 2018 because I was sick of notifications popping up on my phone and iPad interrupting me while trying to read. I loved that I could focus on reading, read in the dark without bothering my boyfriend and that the battery life was so amazing!I upgraded to the Kindle Oasis in 2020 and loved the elevated experience, but I noticed the battery didn't last nearly as long as my Kindle Paperwhite. Which is incredibly disappointing when the Kindle Oasis is so expensive. To be honest the whole reason I bought the Special Edition version is because I read the battery life was so good and has ample amount of storage in it, probably more than I could ever need in this lifetime.The other thing I noticed about the Special Edition version, that I did not hear a single review mention on YouTube or TikTok,  is how super responsive the screen is! I swear, to me it  seems to respond faster than either of the previous models I have owned before. A super nice surprise. I personally love having the long battery life because I mostly read laying down and the last thing I want is to have to charge it while I'm reading, just too restrictive for me. I would get the Special Edition version if you really love downloading and keeping a ton of books to read for leisure and/or read a lot of books or PDFs for school. I think 32 gb would go along way if I were using this as a student exclusively in place of physical books.Overall, if I had to pick from the three versions of Kindle I have owned, I would go with the Oasis version. If like me, you really hate having to move your hand to tap the screen to go to the next or previous page. Want a more premiere reading experience don't really care that you have to charge more often, this is checks all the boxes.

title: Very easy on eyes compared to phone, tablet
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on December 21, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I purchased this 2021 model e-reader to replace my 2018 model that was getting glitchy. I have other electronic devices to read on but I don't get nearly the eye fatigue with the e-reader. This newer version has a warmth setting which improves the comfort factor over the older model.  It's more like reading a physical book, but with the advantages of adjustments for different lighting conditions and desired font size, among other helpful settings. So, A+ for that.The touchscreen still has shortcomings. Overall it seems like prehistoric software. When I tap to turn the page, I frequently turn 2 pages instead of one. I don't have that problem using kindle app on other devices. On the e-reader,  I have to hit letters just right when typing in information or the letter doesn't type. Overall, response to touch input is laggy. Scrolling is better than on 2018 model but still scrolling in any direction is slow and awkward. All of these problems are somewhat alleviated by using the kindle app on phone or tablet for all functions except downloading book to the e reader and reading the book. I select, purchase, browse, and organize books using kindle app on my phone. Then I download the book I'm going to read to the e-reader and read it. When I'm finished, I go back to kindle app on my phone to remove book from Home or return it Kindle Unlimited. Then I select the next book I want to read and download it to my phone. Finally, I download the book to the e-reader and read it. Downloading the book to the phone first makes downloading to e-reader more straightforward.The slightly larger size of the 2021 version does enhance reading without any drawbacks that I've noticed. I can read more before needing to turn page and that seems to facilitate a faster reading rate.Depending on the book, you don't see the page number on the pages. There are steps to determine the page number but not nearly as convenient as actually seeing the page number on the page. The same goes for percentage of book finished and the total number of pages in the book. I am reading a book now that doesn't show page # or % of book read on the pages of the book.

title: New 32 gig Paperwhite, 11th generation
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 23, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I bought this 32 gig version of the Paperwhite to replace my 4 year old 4 gig version. The micro USB charging opening on my old one is loose, so it's very hard to charge it. Only one or two of my many cords will even work, and I have to be careful not to bump it, or the charging stops. The new one charges with a C, which is far superior to the old micro USB type charging cord. I bought the 32 gig version this time because I have a few thousand ebooks, and I like having the ones I want to read already downloaded and ready to go. It will hold a lot more ebooks than the old 4 gig. This new reading screen area is wider and taller in the new Paperwhite compared to the old one. I also like that there's a wider variety of reading screen shades/darkness available to use on the new one. There's a warmth schedule that you can set either automatically or manually for a certain time span.  You can customize the amount of warmth, too. There's also a "nightlight" that will decrease brightness over time as your eyes adjust to darkness, and of course there is an adjustment you can use to increase the regular brightness of the screen. I have set my new Paperwhite so that the screensaver is the cover of the book I am currently reading, which is a nice feature instead of an advertisement. The page turn feature is accessed through the font option in the book you're reading, and can be set for page turn animation or just a page change when you tap or brush the right or left of the screen, and mine is working just fine, with a quick page change. I bought a Fintie cover for my new Paperwhite, and it has a magnetic feature so that the cover remains open until I close it. There's a stand I can set up to read hands free, and when the cover is closed, the Paperwhite goes to sleep. This cover is lower than the ereader's bottom switch, so there is no chance I will accidentally trigger the bottom switch on the ereader. I also haven't had any of the glitches on the new Paperwhite that have been reported by other reviewers, my new ereader has worked wonderfully. So far, this Paperwhite has been much more of a quality ereader compared to my old one, and I'm a satisfied customer.

text: This is my 6th kindle and the worst. I don’t know who designed the technology but they certainly did not make it user friendly. I was recently on a cruise vacation in Europe and had downloaded a variety of books for my trip. However, although I download them I never open them until I’m ready to read each book. I was on a 9 hour flight and finished one book and went to open a new one-it wouldn’t open even though I was able to access the planes WiFi. So there I was without a book for the remainder of the flight. We stayed in Europe at a hotel for 2 days and again the same problem. Once we were on the ship and logged into there WiFi I thought there would be no problem, wrong again, I could not open any of the books I downloaded. I went to the ships WiFi specialists and they did everything possible for 30 minutes (2) technicians, no luck. So there I was 10 day trip, $100.+Worth of books and could not open even one. title: Fantastic!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: I had been debating getting an e-reader for a long time. I've always been a fan of books, but just never had the motivation to read (much less have room for) them. This device changed that in a day. Wow, am I glad I bought this.First, let me start by saying that this tablet is an e-reader, nothing more. If you're looking for color screens, apps, fancy looks, and audio, get a Kindle Fire 10 tablet. This device is only designed to read books (with Bluetooth audio devices, if needed). If you must have audio, a trick I used was to access Audible on your regular tablet or computer, listen to the audio of your book through regular speakers and just read along. This worked great since I had trouble locating my JLab headphones.Next, the touch screen. It is very sensitive (and yes, I agree with everyone complaining about the power button. Just watch where you hold it!). However, it's a minor complaint. The e-ink is amazing. In the right lighting conditions, it resembles an actual page from a book. I had to do a double take to make sure I was still holding a tablet in my hands. The battery life is stellar, I've only gone through only 15% of the battery in 3 days of reading 2-3 hours at a time.  The backlighting can be automatically adjusted to time of day and room conditions, which is a big help when you want to read before going to bed. The warm amber color is very much appreciated.Finally, storage space. If you're a heavy Audible or ChristianAudio user, the 8GB will fill up quickly. I got the 32GB just in case since I prefer reading and listening at the same time.I am super glad I made the jump to an e-reader and am currently reading "Your Brain's Not Broken" by Tamara Rosier. Now I can sell some of my surplus books for a little extra cash to people who need them and open up some space in my apartment. Thank you, Amazon! You've really struck gold with this Paperwhite Kindle! Final note, college students, you can get this at a 30% discount with the promo code 30KINDLE. I used it and it saved me a ton of money on this.

location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2022
options: Color: Black | Option: Without Kindle Unlimited
text: This kindle is exactly what I needed! I work 12 hour shifts basically as a night guard so I have nothing much to do other than read, and I can get through each week without needing to charge up. If I read the entire time I usually have between 40-50% battery left. I saw a lot of people complain about the power button being on the bottom, and I've definitely hit it a couple times but it's not a big enough problem to really bother me. I love the readability and size, sometimes the touch screen has a little bit of an issue where it doesn't register or I have to hit a certain area for it to register, but it's not a deal breaker by any means. It's just really nice to have all my books ready to go wherever I am without any other apps or messaging capabilities to distract me. The screen doesn't hurt my eyes, and the size is big enough to read without being so big it wears my wrist out holding it up. My only complaint is that the screen doesn't allow for color, which I didn't think about beforehand, so I can't really read any of the comics I've purchased on it. All in all I'm very glad to have made this purchase!

text: This is so much better than the first Kindle I had a long time ago!  My dad bought it for me as a gift, and I absolutely hated it!  (This was maybe around 2010 or so.)  However, I just started to get into reading again and a lot of the books I wanted were only in digital format.  I decided to bite the bullet and buy a kindle.  Amazon actually had a good deal on them as they just so happened to be on sale that weekend.  This kindle is absolutely great!  I absolutely love it!!!  It is so much better than the kindles from 10-12 years ago!!!  I was on the fence about getting the kindle with the page buttons.  It is really not necessary to spend the extra cash on it.  Just tapping the right of the screen to change pages is super easy and not inconvenient at all.  Plus, the kindle is already light-weight and ergonomic as it is.  Do not see the need to spend extra cash on those features.  This kindle is great!!  Plus, I got a great deal on it due to the sale!!  Very happy with my purchase!

text: I had an older version that I managed to lose, I swear it's in the house somewhere, and now that I've bought a replacement it will show up.  That one was a bit smaller and just a general version.I'm loving the larger screen, the ability to change screen for blue light, the speed is better and I chose better RAM and more storage. My most favorite thing is night mode!  😍😍 I have very light Sensitive eyes and have a hard time with bright screens. Even dimming the Brightness it is hard to read on white screens.The battery life is amazing.  I can leave it for a week or two, depending how much I read.  I don't use the wireless charger, since when I think of charging it I'm using it so just plug it in, USB 2.0.I also chose the unit that didn't have the ads on the close screen so I have a choice between the pictures they have or the cover of the current novel I'm reading.I bought the package that came with a cover and the wireless charger.  The cover is very nice, fits in the charger. Allows the device to turn on when you open it.  The device will auto shut off even when the case is opened.I'm very happy with this purchase, maybe I'll eventually use the wireless charger;apparently you can charge the Galaxy phones on it. I haven't tried this yet.
